story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'Our ability to hold blockbuster exhibitions while having to pay import duties would be really problematic,' says V&ampA directorClick to followIndy PoliticsSome of the UK's most prestigious museums could be forced to cancel exhibitions&nbspif Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal, according to a batch of&nbspsecret memos.Major visitor attractions such as the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Natural History Museum and the National Museums of Liverpool have expressed&nbspgrave concerns about the costs of importing foreign artworks, falling tourist numbers and&nbspstaffing shortages in the event of a no-deal Brexit.A memo from the V&ampA to the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport&nbspwarned it could be compelled to close its doors temporarily&nbspas 44 per cent of customer service staff are EU nationals, and claimed that&nbsprecruitment difficulties could hamper its plans for&nbspa&nbspnew venue in Stratford.Brexit deal will be agreed within three weeks, Dominic Raab tells MPsThe South Kensington-based attraction also said it could face&nbspup to £25m&nbspimport costs on its loans for future exhibitions.Papers from the Natural History Museum said it could be left £2m out of pocket through a loss of research funding, while an estimated 15 per cent decline in foreign tourists could cost £2.4m.The Royal Museums Greenwich said a chaotic exit could mean&nbspshipment of art items are&nbsptwice as costly in the short term, while the National Museums Liverpool warned that&nbspvisa and customs issues could&nbspaffect costs and timings for programmes.The fears were laid bare in&nbspa freedom of information request by the People's Vote, which is calling&nbspfor a&nbspreferendum on Theresa May's&nbspBrexit deal, an aim backed by The Independent's Final Say campaign.V&ampA director Tristram Hunt, a former Labour shadow cabinet member, told the Evening Standard: “Our ability to hold blockbuster exhibitions while having to pay import duties would be really problematic.Brexit: EU steps up no-deal planning as clock counts down on talksSurge in Irish passports applications from UK residents, figures showNo-deal Brexit would tip the UK into a ‘long recession’, warns S&ampPHome Office 'risking repeat of Windrush scandal for EU citizens'UK and Norway agree deal to protect citizens' rights in no-deal Brexit“Our ability to promote British soft power and influence through exhibitions like David Bowie Is and Pink Floyd would be seriously compromised.“That’s bad for the London visitor economy. Four in five visitors to London come for the culture, and they are drawn by great museums and world class exhibitions. It is also potentially damaging for British influence abroad.”Ahead of the referendum, senior Brexiteers&nbspwarned that leaving the EU&nbspwould not affect the creative industries.In an open letter signed by top Tories such as Boris Johnson, Michael Gove, Dominic Raab, Chris Grayling and Iain Duncan Smith, Vote Leave claimed that funding for cultural organisations would be unaffected by Brexit.Labour former culture secretary Ben Bradshaw&nbspsaid: “The mess created by the Brexit elite in Westminster is now casting a long shadow over the future of our great museums.Created with Sketch.Britain before Brexit: East of England Show all 13Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A couple and their dog relax by the Cathedral’s Labyrinth. I am charmed by the arrangement of their bodies and the shapes in which they are bonding. I realise the contemporary significance of the scene: the labyrinth - a complicated, irregular network of passages in which it is difficult to find one’s way - alongside the simplicity and closeness of human togetherness. In any complicated maze-like structure - Brexit included - it is important to remember that people and love and relationships are a vital part of the picture.Walking back into town from Leagrave High Street I notice two graffitied propaganda messages: ‘Free Gaza’ and ‘Beverly is a black cow’. Here are but two voices, I think, in the crazy cacophony of contemporary British discourse, of the British tongue, fractured as it is into accents, splintered by slangs, torn, in this case, into the libertarian and abusive, one dehumanising, one for freedom.University students hold a flash protest against the low pay of McDonald’s employees. They receive tuts, cheers, insults, whoops, raised eyebrows. People enter the restaurant in any case, unaware or uncaring that they have crossed a picket line.I went to look inside the Catholic Cathedral during Mass. I wanted to see the ritual and the practices, the people and their poses. There is a rich spectrum of visual dimensions to Catholic prayer that I first noticed when photographing in Poland. I’m attracted to its ambivalence: solemn and joyous lonely in dialogue desperate but determined solitary yet complete.Posters from the town’s glory days surround the Winter Gardens as it rusts and becomes overgrown. It seems like an intentional act to rekindle nostalgia in the face of disrepair, to balance the present with representations of the past.At the back of the central market hang three representations of conflict, side-by-side, connected, making sense in relation to one another. the entrance to its headquartersThe EU has moved to step up planning for a no-deal Brexit as the clock runs down on stalled negotiations that could see the UK crash out of the bloc without an agreement.There have been no signs of progress in Brussels since the meeting of the European Council a fortnight ago, when the EU’s 27 leaders scrapped plans for a November summit to finalise a deal, stating that not enough progress had been made.With the original October deadline for a deal now officially in the past, officials behind the scenes still remain hopeful that a withdrawal agreement can be struck – though there are few clues to how or when.UK and Norway agree deal to protect citizens' rights in no-deal BrexitSpeaking at lunchtime on Wednesday a spokesperson for the European Commission told reporters: “I’m not currently in a position to confirm when the next meeting of the negotiators will take place.”A committee of member states’ EU ambassadors that organises behind-the-scenes heavy lifting met in Brussels on Wednesday and agreed to organise a series of seminars to work out details of the EU’s response to a no-deal.The sessions will cover planning for issues such as what would happen to flights between the UK and EU, the protection of citizens’ rights, how border controls would operate, and whether the Eurostar and freight trains could still use the channel tunnel.Speaking at the Commission’s headquarters in the Berlaymont building, the EU spokesperson added added: “Contact at technical level continues… the Commission will debrief Coreper this afternoon on the latest state of play this afternoon of negotiations. This is just a routine update of the state of play of negotiations. I’ve got no juicy details to give you I’m afraid.”Surge in Irish passports applications from UK residents, figures showUK to recruit 1,000 more diplomatic staff to keep clout after BrexitHome Office 'not being straight' with MPs over Brexit border securityA UK government spokesperson said: “We want to get a deal as soon as possible and agreed in the autumn. title: george osborne newsnight bbc polly toynbee interview austerity benefits poverty brexit
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options‘This man has done such harm and damage to this country,’&nbspformer chancellor toldClick to followIndy PoliticsGeorge Osborne&nbsphas defended the&nbspgovernment’s programme of austerity after enduring a verbal assault during an appearance on the BBC’s&nbspNewsnight.The former chancellor – who admitted his administration had made mistakes that contributed to the Brexit vote –&nbspinsisted the UK had to “live within its means” after being told his “treatment of the poorest people in this country has been despicable”.Mr Osborne, now editor of the London&nbspEvening Standard, sister title to The Independent, was invited on the programme after his successor Philip Hammond claimed the “era of austerity is finally coming to an end” in this&nbspweek’s Budget.The end of austerity has ended already. It lasted for over 19 hoursOsborne stuck with public sector pay cap despite child poverty warningFellow guest on the show, writer&nbspPolly Toynbee,&nbspsaid the former Conservative MP&nbspwho oversaw the government’s policy of austerity&nbsphad “done such harm and damage to this country”, branding him “the most right-wing chancellor we have ever had”.The columnist tore into Mr Osborne after Newsnight presenter Evan Davis suggested the former chancellor was “closer to Polly Toynbee’s politics than you are to two-thirds of Conservative Party members”.Ms Toynbee described the&nbspcomparison as “unthinkable”.“This man has done such harm and damage to this country,” she added. “He has been the most right-wing chancellor we have ever had.”The journalist said Mr Osborne had taken billions from Britain’s poorest through benefit cuts “and then abused them with that endless talk about people with their blinds down, trying to make people hate anyone on benefits, despite the fact that the great majority of them are in work, often working in two jobs”.She told the ex-MP: “Your treatment of the poorest people in this country has been despicable.”Asked by Mr Davis if he had any regrets about his time in office, the former chancellor admitted government errors had led to Brexit.“We were wrong to play into the debate that everything that Brussels did was a challenge and a battle and was wrong,” he said.The Conservative government had also set targets on&nbspcutting immigration “that we couldn’t deliver and that then led to a debate about how you might deliver those targets”, he conceded.“We definitely contributed to that argument, didn’t make enough of the value of immigration.”He went on to urge Theresa May’s government not to attempt to compete with Labour on government spending.“The Conservatism I think that works is socially progressive and fiscally conservative – and we lost in the election I wasn’t&nbspinvolved in 2017 because we tried to out-Ukip&nbspUkip,” he said.“We aren’t going to win the next election by trying to out-Corbyn Corbyn.“The Conservatives should stand their ground for what I think still millions of people are, they want a progressive, successful country, you’ve got to live within your means... trying to outspend our political opponents won’t help the Conservatives either.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to sentiments that you express are ones we absolutely share,” confirmed Mr Gove.The Labour MP told the ministers this was a real point of concern for the farming community, and “all the subsidies we give to British farmers would be pretty meaningless if they could be undercut by lower quality cheap imports where they cut corners”.Committee chair and Conservative MP Neil Parish echoed these concerns, citing the recent visit of US agriculture secretary Sonny Perdue.“He talked really nothing but getting access to our market for their chicken,” said Mr Parish.Ditch US trade deal rather than accept lower food standards, Brits sayThe US uses different techniques to avoid contamination and infection in its livestock, washing chicken carcasses with chlorine and reportedly using up to five times as many antibiotics in their animals.Mr Eustice acknowledged these differences, stating: “The US approach is much more: turn a blind eye to what might happen on the farm and treat it when it gets to the abattoir.“It’s a different culture and they don’t have a culture of putting animal welfare in a particularly prominent position either.”Given these concerns, Mr Parish told the ministers “you have got to protect us against imports”.“I don’t see what harm it would do in the agriculture bill, then at least when a trade deal comes along when we are debating it in the House of Commons we can say in the agriculture bill it refers to maintaining those standards when we import food.“Why are you so adamant it can’t go there when your whole raison d’etre of British agriculture in the future is to have high welfare and environment standards?” he asked the ministers.Responding to the hearing, a spokesperson from the National Farmers’ Union said: “British farming operates to some of the highest standards in the world.“The recent Efra&nbspCommittee The Future of Food, Farming and the Environment&nbspreport recommended that the government does not enter into trade agreements that allow food imports that do not meet our environmental, welfare and food safety standards.“It is vital that British farming’s produce and contribution to the nation is not undermined.”Ms McCarthy said she planned to table an amendment to the bill to try to get these protections enshrined in law.The proposals suggested by Mr Gove include payments to farmers for environmental services such as curbing flooding and improving access to the countryside.They have been heralded as part of the government’s plan to deliver a “green Brexit”, but some members of the Efra&nbspCommittee said there were fears among farmers that the plans will come at the expense of food production.Mr Eustice said he hoped to have the agriculture bill finalised before the end of the year or early next year, before the Brexit date IndependentSebastian Kurz and his girlfriend Susanne ThierAustria is set to follow the United States and Hungary by backing out of a United Nations migration pact.The right-wing Austrian government, which took office last December, has said it will not sign the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration which looks to make migration safer.&nbspAustrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz stood on an anti-immigration platform and since taking office in December has implemented a number of policies that include restricting benefits for new immigrants.Austria will not join the UN migration pact,&nbspMr Kurz said in a statement.Protesters block street to stop immigration officers detaining manHostile environment failing to deter illegal migrants, report finds Trump pick to lead UN migrant group has ‘pushed fear of Sharia law' Trump nominee for UN migration post called Muslims violentWe view some points of the migration pact very critically, such as the mixing up of seeking protection with labour migration.”Austria took in roughly one per cent of its population in asylum seekers in 2015 during a migration crisis in which more than a million people travelled to Europe, many of them fleeing war and poverty in the Middle East, Africa and elsewhere.The non-binding UN pact is aimed at making migration safe and orderly.&nbspIt addresses issues such as how to protect story: Prince Charles, Britain&rsquos future King, had a close relationship with his grandmother which blossomed from a very young age.She is said to have &ldquoencouraged his &ldquokind and gentle nature and his love for music as she adored young children and was happy to indulge in them.Royal author Gill Knappett says &ldquoshe gave the young Charles hugs, encouraged his kind and gentle nature and introduced him to the world of music and art.Prince Charles described her as &ldquoquite simply the most magical grandmother you could possibly have. story: The 92-year-old monarch has been holding private meetings with her eldest son for months to discuss the matters of state.Furthermore, the Prince of Wales has been added to the distribution list of despatch boxes that the Queen is sent from Whitehall.Royal expert Robert Jobson has said these steps are being taken so that if the Queen makes it 95 then she will transfer all executive powers to the Charles, making him the Prince Regent.He wrote in the Daily Mail: &ldquoIn the event of her death or inability to continue through illness, the Queen has ensured that her heir is fully primed and ready to take over.                Kate Middleton&rsquos private meeting with the Queen before Royal Wedding&ldquoSome close to the monarch say that, if she reaches the age of 95, she will make a monumental decision and choose to officially allow Charles to take over the stewardship of her reign.&ldquoShe will, they say, officially transfer all executive powers to him as Prince Regent until her death, when he will become king.&nbsp&ldquoThis would enable her to fudge the issue of her not fulfilling her Coronation Oath to God and her people to serve as queen regnant until her death.The Prince of Wales has already taken on more responsibility by travelling overseas to represent her, as he is this week in west Africa.&nbspThe Queen could make Prince Charles the Prince Regent in three years (Image: )He also reportedly works 14-hour days and carries out more than 600 engagements a year.&nbspMr Jobson said this illustrates how &ldquoit is, in effect, a job-share monarchy, with the heir leading the way for the House of Windsor, not following.The Queen is in good health and could live to be a centenarian like her mother, but royal experts are confident the monarch has ensured there will be &ldquothe smoothest of successions with the minimum of fuss.The last time the Regency Act was invoked was in 1810 during the reign of George III when he became mentally unwell.Sources say the Queen could make Charles the Prince Regent in three years (Image: )His eldest son took the title Prince Regent and when his father died 10 years later he became George IV.The Regency Act was reformed in 1937 to allow for a Regency if &ldquothe Sovereign is for some definite cause not available for the performance of those functions.However, the list of causes is not specified leading to speculation that it is vague enough for the monarchs to allow their heirs to succeed.

story: The revelation has been spotted in the mind-blowing sub-atomic world where particles are mere wisps of existence and only survive for microseconds &ndash but the new science could see 100 years of accepted physics thrown in the bin.The discovery is so troubling it threatens to undermine the so-called Standard Model &ndash the bedrock of all modern physics and an attempt to formulate a theory of everything.Leading British physicist Tara Shears who carries out research at the famous atom-smasher in Cern, Switzerland, said if the anomaly &ndash which is still being analysed &ndash turns out to be correct it would &ldquobreak science.She added: &ldquoAs a particle physicist its as big as Einstein.                END OF THE WORLD: THIS is how Earth and the universe will be DESTROYED                Alzheimer's BREAKTHROUGH: Scientists discover cause in world first&ldquoIt&rsquos hugely exciting because it would lead to us breaking science and would have huge implications.The Standard Model was the dream of major scientists from Einstein to Hawking &ndash and many physicists believed humanity was drawing closer to a final theory which explained everything in the universe.But the new LHC discovery has confounded the scientists&rsquo optimism.Initially physicists at the massive LHC dismissed the new findings as a mistake or a quirk of the seven-mile long collider.But repeated identical findings of the freakish movements of an infinitesimally small particle known as a Muon seemed to prove conclusive.Artist&#157s impression of a superconducting magnet for LHC (Image: )More importantly the data could not be explained away using established norms of theoretical physics.In an interview with Express Ms Shears, Professor of Physics at the University of Liverpool, said normally particles behaved in line with the predictions of theoretical physics &ndash in, in this case when an electron decays two particles known as Taus and Muons should be spat out.However LHC researchers discovered Muons were not adhering the physics of the Standard Model and were being spat out 25 percent less than they should be.Ms Shears said: &ldquoMuons were produced 25 percent less often than electrons and that cannot happen in the Standard Model.Tara Shears Professor of Physics at University of Liverpool speaking at New Scientist Live (Image: Paul Baldwin)&ldquoThat can only happen if there&rsquos new physics out there.&ldquoThe LHC findings are 25 percent too low and we are eagerly awaiting the outcome of this data &ndash if it stays like this then this would be the first sign of something genuinely new out there.&ldquoWe have no idea what it is &ndash it&rsquos nothing we&rsquove known before.Scientists hope solving the Muon anomaly puzzle will shed light on the biggest prize in physics &ndash the problem of Dark Matter and its associated Dark Energy.Ms Shears said: &ldquoThat is the next step in this adventure.&ldquoMany people thought we would find evidence of dark matter and our testing is still very hopeful&ldquoThis is bigger than the Higgs Bosun, it is Nobel Prize winning stuff, it tells us what the universe is made of&ldquoWe are desperate to find answers to these questions &ndash but we are just seeing measurements that don&rsquot fit.Ms Shears was a guest speaker at the recent&nbspthe New Scientist Live expo in London.&nbsp

story: European capitals were told not to expect an appearance from Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab anytime soon as technical-level negotiations rumble on in the background.EU ambassadors were summoned for a so-called &lsquoCoreper&rsquo meeting to be told UK and EU officials are still yet to make any further progress in the Brexit negotiations.Talks remain deadlocked after EU leaders decided they could go no further without a significant political offer from Theresa May at the most recent European Council summit in Brussels.Member states were treated to a mundane &lsquostate of play&rsquo briefing from Sabine Weyand, the trusty deputy of chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier.                Brexit BOOST: Brussels says London will STILL be key finance hub                We must woo Britain back to a NEW EU warns ex-French leader SarkozyOther preparations were made for an Article 50 meeting of European affairs ministers scheduled for November 12, according to an EU source close to the negotiations.European capitals are intent that a political-level intervention is required to kickstart the stalled negotiations but Commission officials are yet to receive any signals from Westminster that Mr Raab is planning his next trip to Brussels.This week, Mrs May&rsquos EU sherpa Olly Robbins made his first appearance in the Belgian capital since talks broke down ahead of the summit.Talks remain deadlocked over the Irish backstop, an insurance mechanism demanded by Brussels to ensure Brexit does not create a hard border on the island of Ireland.Brexit news: EU waits on Dominic Raab to make political progress in negotiations (Image: )The EU&rsquos offer is highly controversial because it essentially locks Northern Ireland into the EU&rsquos customs union and many of its single market rules.Mrs May issued a warning that &ldquono prime minister could accept such a proposal to ease the nerves of Brexiteers and the Democratic Unionist Party over the possible annexation of the province.Because of this standoff, virtually no progress on Ireland has been made since the UK rejected Mr Barnier&rsquos proposal in March.With only 149 days till Britain officials leaves the EU, member states have once again ramped up their no-deal orce planning.                &lsquoTERROR WILL WIN!' David Davis warns May against CAVING IN to EU                Brexiteer MP jokes 'iffy' Hammond is now the KING of BrexitCapitals agreed on Tuesday that they should host a series of no-deal planning seminars in November.They will cover a number of issues from citizens&rsquo rights, aviation, customs, border controls, financial services and ground transport.Despite the added urgency for creating contingency plans for the possibility of Britain crashing out of the bloc without a deal, Brussels remains adamant that an agreement is still possible.An EU Commission spokeswoman said: &ldquoWe want to reach a deal with the United Kingdom and its orderly withdrawal from the European Union.&ldquoWe&rsquore going on with our technical-level contacts and Michel Barnier remains available to resume at a political-level as soon as the right time is found.A UK Government spokesman said: &ldquoWe want to get a deal as soon as possible and agreed in the autumn.&ldquoWe will continue to work with the EU to make this happen.

story: Michael, from Chelmsford, rang into the LBC radio show to discuss the potential trading benefits of leaving the EU.But when the discourse turned to a deal with America, Mr O&rsquoBrien repeatedly talked over his caller before announcing that he would ask physicist Brian Cox the question of why leaving the EU was detrimental to the UK economy instead.Mr Cox stepped in and replied simply: &ldquoBecause the EU is a terrifically large market and we&rsquore a smaller market.The patronising attempt to derail Michael was reinforced when the LBC host asked rhetorically: &ldquoIs that good enough for you, Michael?                Nick Ferrari in STITCHES as caller puts him ON HOLD during live show                'Sounds like a RUDE joke!' Rees-Mogg baffled by Apu backlashMichael uttered a reasonable reply to the simplistic assertion: &ldquoUm, no not really.But rather than let him expand, the radio host laughed and said: &ldquoYeah&hellipokay, well Michael I love you like a brother but I don&rsquot know how long I&rsquove got the professor in the studio for and it&rsquos a little unprofessional of me to bombard him with that question.As Michael attempted to respond, Mr O&rsquoBrien interrupted and turned his attention entirely to Brian Cox.He said: &ldquoBrian Cox - how come we&rsquove never met before, I can&rsquot believe it.James O'Brien used Brian Cox to cut-off caller (Image: LBC)The professor appeared to discuss his upcoming 2019 world tour titled Universal: Adventures in Space and Time that kicks off in Derby in February.The star revealed on The One Show this morning that he has sold out Wembley and now has plans to continue his tour until September next year, taking his show to London's O2 Arena.

title: no deal brexit news theresa may philip hammond uk business wto terms
story: The Prime Minister and Chancellor Philip Hammond will meet with executives and investors in a bid to ease fears over the possibility of Britain quitting the European Union without a withdrawal agreement in place.Some 120 business leaders will attend the meeting, which will focus on this week&rsquos Budget announcement and give business leaders chances to put questions to the pair.But the summit, which is taking place in an undisclosed location, will likely see concerns voiced over the growing potential of a no-deal Brexit.With just months left to secure an exit deal, major firms have complained over a lack of certainty on the sort of trade terms they can expect after the orce.                The major hurdles left to clear with just FIVE MONTHS until Brexit day                Brexit news: EU doesn't trust May enough to offer her Irish compromiseThe prospect of no deal is particularly worrying for some firms because the previously agreed 21-month transition period - designed to give businesses time to adapt to life outside the EU - is based on a deal being struck.Earlier this month, Japanese carmaker Nissan became the latest in growing list of manufacturers to warn of job losses at its UK operations if Britain leaves the bloc on World Trade Organisation (WTO) terms.But Brexiteers insist WTO terms would give British businesses a clean break from EU regulations and allow the UK to strike trade free trade deals with countries around the world.Talks are currently deadlocked over the Irish border issue, which has proved to be the biggest stumbling block in the 16 months of negotiations.No-deal Brexit: Nissan and Airbus have expressed major concern over no deal (Image: PA IMAGES)Theresa May and Philip Hammond were pictured leaving Downing Street earlier today (Image: REUTERS)                Brexit BOOST: Brussels says London will STILL be key finance hub                EU must beg Britain back into a NEW EU warns ex-French leader SarkozyBoth sides are refusing to budge in their demands over the so-called backstop solution - measures to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic if a wider exit deal is not struck.It emerged this week that Dublin is drawing up plans for a hard Brexit which would see more patrols and checkpoints along the politically-sensitive frontier.Meanwhile, former Brexit Secretary and ardent Leave supporter David Davis warned Mrs May would likely end up agreeing to terms with Brussels just to avoid the &ldquoirrational fear of leaving without a deal.Speaking at an event at the Institute of Economic Affairs, Mr Davis was asked for his predictions on the outcome of Brexit.Nissan has warned of 'serious implications' for its UK operations if no deal is reached (Image:  IMAGES)Former Brexit Secretary David Davis said there is an 'irrational fear' over WTO terms (Image:  IMAGES)He said: Terror will win.The fear of no deal, I think - we haven't had a chance to talk about it much - but I think that's an irrational fear of no deal or a WTO deal.That will win and there will be a deal.It may take a few passes, there maybe a deal passes in Brussels and fails in Westminster.Today&rsquos meeting between Mrs May and business leaders comes after a conference call the Prime Minister held with a similar-sized group of executives earlier this month.

title: Brexit news UK EU withdrawal agreement deal Guy Verhofstadt Dominic Raab latest
story: Brexit news: Guy Verhofstadt claims Dominic Raab sunk completed withdrawal deal (Image: )The Brexit Secretary refused to give Government backing for a technical-level deal concluded between UK and European Union officials ahead of the October European Council summit.Mr Verhofstadt, the EU Parliament&rsquos Brexit co-ordinator, confirmed Brussels was confident the tabled withdrawal agreement would be agreed during dinner meeting of prime ministers.But Mr Raab sunk any possibility of the deal being concluded during his meeting with the EU&rsquos chief negotiator on October 14.Mr Raab told Mr Barnier the UK Government wouldn&rsquot be able to back the agreement, according to Mr Verhofstadt.At this point, the Brexit Secretary&rsquos intervention &ldquomade the conclusion of an agreement at the forthcoming European Council meeting impossible.In minutes from the European Parliament&rsquos Conference of Presidents meeting, Mr Verhofstadt confirms &ldquothere had been hope for an agreement based on a global proposal on a withdrawal agreement.But during his last Brussels meeting, Mr Raab &ldquoinformed Mr Barnier that that proposal would not be backed by the UK Government, which had made the conclusion of an agreement at the forthcoming European Council meeting impossible.At the summit, which was just three days later, European leaders decided &ldquodecisive progress had not been made and they shelved plans for an emergency November summit.                Brexit news: EU ramps up no-deal preparation as they wait for Raab                Brexit news: EU doesn't trust May enough to offer her Irish compromiseFrench President Emmanuel Macron told reporters the EU had offered its last compromise and it is time for Theresa May to make the next political move.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos no longer a technical issue, it&rsquos for the political ability of the UK to reach an agreement that can be presented to us.&ldquoIt&rsquos not for the EU to make concessions to deal with UK political issues. I can not be more clear on this.&ldquoMrs May has been extremely committed and I&rsquom convinced she will work in finding a political solution to get back to the EU negotiators.Talks have since been deadlocked, with the Irish border remaining the main sticking point. On Wednesday, EU ambassadors were told there had been &ldquono radical breakthrough during ongoing negotiations.In a letter to the House of Common&rsquos Brexit Committee chairman, Mr Raab claims he is confident a Brexit deal can be concluded in late November.After Hilary Benn asked the Brexit Secretary to give evidence to the committee, Mr Raab, in a letter dated October 24, replied: &ldquoI would be happy to give evidence to the Committee when a deal is finalised, and currently expect November 21 to be suitable.While EU officials have not totally ruled out a November summit, Mr Raab&rsquos timeline is deemed optimistic with the December European Council a more likely venue.

of the &ldquoabsolute unaccountability of the European Commission.The Tory Brexiteer ridiculed the EU &ldquogravy train before launching a furious rant at the European Commission.Speaking to Express, Mr Jones said: &ldquoIt&rsquos always characterised as a gravy train but that is because it is a gravy train.&ldquoYou&rsquove got MEPs who are given so-called expenses payments on top of their salaries which they can spend any way that they want.&ldquoAnd I think that this is just characteristic of the European Union as a whole. There is an immense waste.&ldquoTheir accounts have never been signed off for the last goodness knows how many years. If that were to happen to a British company there would be an outcry.&ldquoBut, of course, it happens there.

story: BBC Weather forecaster Mel Coles warned wind speeds will pick up to as high as 65 miles per hour for northeastern parts of Britain on Friday evening and into the weekend.The BBC Weather forecaster warned that despite temperatures picking up on Wednesday and Thursday, the weather will take a turn for the worst on Friday.The BBC host said: &ldquoTemperatures not doing too badly through Thursday that rain gradually clears away as we head towards Thursday night and into Friday.&ldquoClear skies &ndash that means temperatures will fall away and another frosty night and then maybe some mist and fog around first thing.                BBC Weather: Britons WARNED of GALES this weekend as Storm Oscar hits                ITV Good Morning Britain: Laura Tobin terrified by guest live on air&ldquoBut actually with a ridge of high pressure, things will be fairly settled for many areas of the UK on Friday.&ldquoSome spells of crisp autumn sunshine around.But the BBC host warned there will be a u-turn in weather conditions on Friday, she said: &ldquoBut things start to turn a little bit downhill as we head towards the latter stages of Friday and that is courtesy of ex-hurricane Oscar.&ldquoIt has been working its way across the Atlantic and that will bring wet and windy conditions into the far&nbspnorth west&nbspof Scotland where we could have gusts of around 65 miles an hour.BBC Weather: Forecaster warns of 65 mph in UK on Friday night (Image: BBC)&ldquoBut with that south westerly flow temperatures will be back into the mid-teens &ndash so noticeably milder but windy on Saturday.The Met Office also warned that despite narrowly avoiding a direct hit on the nation, the remnants of Hurricane Oscar will still cause strong winds for northeastern parts of the country.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: &ldquoAt some point on Thursday and Friday the hurricane will transition into what we call an extratropical depression.&ldquoIn other words, a typical area of low pressure with weather fronts, wind and rain and so on.&ldquoThen it is likely to head to the north-west of the UK during the weekend.&ldquoNow, a few days ago some of the computers models were predicting a more direct hit for the UK. Thankfully, it is now moving to the north and it looks most likely that it will be the far northwest that experiences the strongest winds.Mr McGivern warned the ex-hurricane could get caught in the jet stream, which could fuel its energy.BBC Weather: Storm to avoid direct hit on UK (Image: CBS news&bullNHC)He said: &ldquoWhat happens when hurricanes move north. They leave warm waters behind so they lose that energy source. But often they can get swept up into the jet stream and that provides another fuel source for these ex-hurricanes and by later Thursday.The Met Office forecaster added: &ldquoBy the end of Friday the winds will be picking up. So Friday is actually a cold, frosty and sunny start for many places.&ldquoA fine day for most of us but we will notice the winds picking up and the cloud building and then on Saturday there is ex-Oscar to the northeast of Britain bringing strong winds to northwestern parts of the country and bringing outbreaks of rain to northern areas.

story: The Ouija is also known as a spirit board or talking board.&nbspThe board tends to be flat and is marked with all the letters of the alphabet, as well as numbers zero to nine.The words &ldquoyes, &ldquono, &ldquohello and &ldquogoodbye are often marked on the board too.&nbspPeople place their fingers of a small heart-shaped piece of wood or plastic called a planchette and it is moved around the board to spell out certain words. Is Satanism an emerging in the UK?The game originated as a fun way for people to ask questions and then see what the planchette would spell out for them.However, after World War One, American spiritualist Pearl Curran started associating the game with the occult.&nbspSpiritualists believed dead people were able to contact the living through the board.Now the Ouija board is generally considered to be part of Halloween.Halloween 2018: Ouija boards are a popular Halloween tradition (Image: ) The Ouija is also known as a spirit board or talking board (Image: )Americans generally regard Halloween to be a major festival and often play games, dress up, and trick or treat around neighbours&rsquo doors to celebrate.&nbspA popular game to play on this spooky day is Spirit in the Glass.&nbspTo play this, you need to be sat around a table that has a smooth surface.In a circle, the letters of the alphabet and the numbers one to nine should be spread out. title: Halloween 2018 are vampires witches real UK Wicca witch covens
story: The spirit of Halloween this year will have many people dishing out horror stories or tuning into their favourite horror flicks.Among these could be the terrifying tale of Dracula, or the Halloween classic witch movie Hocus Pocus.With witches and vampires on the mind, some may wonder whether the paranormal is real.Express is on hand with all the origins of the creatures.                Brexit news: EU ramps up no-deal preparation as they wait for Raab                Halloween 2018: How to play on Ouija board or Spirit in the Glass?Are vampires real?Vampires originated in folklore dating from the 19th century, in books such as Bram Stoker&rsquos &lsquoDracula&rsquo.They are a classic backbone to halloween, as their human-like forms make easy costumes with just a dash of blood and some plastic pointed teeth.Even though they are ultimately Halloween indulgences, they have their real-world counterparts.Their appearance and explanation is theorised to be from dated understandings of human bodily composition.Halloween 2018- Are vampires and witches REAL? Are there witch covens in the UK? (Image: )According to the book Vampires, Burial and Death by Paul Barber, societies once suspected vampirism in bodies which didn&rsquot look quite right after being dug up.People would have attributed the look to being &lsquoundead&rsquo - still being alive despite the outward appearance of death.In addition, the spread of diseases and death around smaller communities was attributed to blood-sucking monsters.Viruses like tuberculosis or the bubonic plague gave victims a drawn appearance and blood on the lips from damaged lungs or throats, contributing to the traditional vampire appearance beliefs.                Life after death: Man crossed to NEW DIMENSION in Halloween NDE                Halloween 2018: What is Satanism? Is Satanism an emerging in the UK?Vampires have a very real basis (Image: )Are witches real?Witches are portrayed often as women with a green pallor and sharp hooked noses.These goblin-like appearances hide their true origin however - as women who were believed to practice magic.The term witchery simply refers to possessing magical abilities and casting spells.Accusations of witchcraft were put towards women who were likely involved in personal disputes or jealousy, and resulted in widespread &lsquowitch trials&rsquo in many places, which sought to test and punish women accused of practicing witchcraft.In reality, witchcraft or sorcery are non-existent, but there are still people alive today who practice the art.Wicca are modern-day witches (Image: )The most famous modern witches are known as Wicca, and are groups of people who gather in &lsquocovens&rsquo to ritually practice magic.For the Wicca, there is &ldquolow magic and &ldquofolk magic which are used to worship deities named the Moon Goddess and Horned God.In order to gather together for worship, witches form &lsquocovens&rsquo which consist of initiated priests and priestesses, headed by a high priest or priestess.The purpose of gathering in covens and performing rituals i according to High Priestess Margot Adler one method of reintegrating iniduals and groups into the cosmos, and to tie in the activities of daily life with their ever present, often forgotten, significance.

story: Francesco Donato, the Director of Eurexit, a non-profit organization campaigning for Italy to abandon the European common monetary system, claimed the eurozone is on the verge of collapse.&nbspMs Donato urged Italy and other member&nbspstates to get out before it is too late, arguing the collapse of the EU institution will eventually force all member states into a recession.&nbspThe former Italian politician told Express member states central to the European Union project will be the first to crash in the event of a sudden collapse of the euro.&nbspAsked if she believed Italy should leave the common project, she said: &ldquoI remain of the same idea because looking at how things are going the probability that sooner or later there will be an uncontrolled collapse of the eurozone is higher and higher.                Italy budget row: Rome TURNS UP HEAT on EU as GDP stagnates - &lsquoTHIS...                EU on BRINK: Italy to STRIKE BACK at Juncker sanctions threats&ldquoIt would be logical if Italy and other member states would plan an organised and controlled exit.&ldquoIf we don&rsquot do that we will get to a point where we will have to leave without notice because we are forced by the European Union itself and by the European Central Bank and this will be traumatic not so much for us but for the European Union.&ldquoThis is a suicidal attitude of the European Union. At the end of the day who will pay the higher price, it will not be Italy but the member states central to the Union like Germany.Rome and Brussels have been&nbspin a stand-off since the European Commission rejected the eurosceptic Government's 2019 budget proposal.Brussels demanded that Rome come up with a revised version within three weeks worthy could face fines up to &pound3billion (&euro3.4bn).Italy has insisted it needs to increase its deficit to 2.4 percent, which breaks EU fiscal rules that are designed to protect the Eurozone.Italy news: Francesca Donato urges the Italian Government to leave the eurozone (Image:    La7 Attualit&agrave)Italy&rsquos projected GDP for 2019 is expected to be &pound1.67trillion (&euro1.87trillion), according to&nbspTrading Economics.If they ignore Brussels and run their deficit of 2.4 percent then their deficit comes to &pound40.01billion (&euro44.88billion).The European Commission demanded Italy would come up with a revised plan within three weeks from their request.&nbspBut in a shifty response, the Italian Government has announced the new practically unchanged proposal will be presented to Parliament on Wednesday.&nbspIt comes as a new ISTAT report revealed Italy's economy has shown little to no growth this year.Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said he was not surprised that Italy&rsquos GDP stagnated in the third quarter this year and said this justified why his country needs to run a bigger deficit.Italy news: Italian Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini pledged to present same budget plan to EU (Image: )Italy news: Italian PM Giuseppe Conte (middle) with Luigi Di Maio (left) and Matteo Salvini (right) (Image: )He said: &ldquoWe had forecast this. That&rsquos why we&rsquoll have this expansive budget.The latest numbers by statistics office ISTAT showed that neither trade nor domestic consumption had picked up.On Tuesday, Italy received a new letter from the European Commission asking for a report on the so-called 'significant factors' that may justify a debtGDP ratio with a less marked reduction than that requested.The Commission demanded a reply by November 13. A similar letter was sent in past years, the Italian ministry said.In the letter, European Commission economic and financial affairs directorate Director General Marco Buti wrote that Italian public debt remains a crucial vulnerability.Writing to Treasury Director-General Andrea Rivera, he said such a high public debt limits the government's room to manoeuvre for more productive spending to benefit its citizens.Buti also said the high debt remains a concern for the eurozone, adding the 2019 budget plan is incompatible with a debt reduction.Italian Professor Antonio Maria Rinaldi claimed an EU sanction to&nbspItaly&nbspover its controversial budget proposals would only amount to 0.2 percent of the country's GDP, a drop in the ocean if compared with the huge economic benefits of the eurosceptic government's plan.The Italian economist claimed the hefty sum would be no higher than &euro4 billion adding the EU is welcome to go ahead with the punitive measure.&nbspMr Rinaldi told Express: &ldquoI hear the EU wants to undertake an infringement procedure?&ldquoThey&rsquore welcome to do so. It will take them nowhere just as it has never taken them anywhere in the past.&ldquoAs a matter of fact, if they went ahead with some pecuniary sanctions as provided by the Treaties and the regulations, they wouldn&rsquot go over the 0.2percent of GDP, something like &euro3 or &euro4 billion, which would be a little thing compared to the advantages Italy could benefit from with a strong budget proposal.&ldquoIf Italy approved a budget with several extra percentage points of deficit which would activate public investments, the advantage would be a lot higher than the potential fine - which I must stress has never been imposed to anyone anyway.READ MORE:&nbspItaly SLAM EU threats as budget tensions escalate

story: China is cracking down on the behaviour of its dogs  (Image: )A dog owner in China can lose points on their social credit score if these rules are not adhered to.Once the dog owner loses 12 points, the authority is able to keep their dog and send the owner to a class to learn how to improve as a pet owner.The first time an owner is caught out, they are given three points, the second time six points and the third tim their points would be knocked down to zero and they would need to attend a dog owners&rsquo class.The programme was launched in 2017 and appears to have been successful as more owners have put their dogs on a leash and cleaned up after them. story: These spooky headlines all sound like they could be taken from the plot of a horror film, but in fact they’re just some of the scariest horror stories to have taken place in Britain.Here, Sun Online takes a look the UK horror stories that are scarier than fiction.In , a man named Bill Ramsey, , took himself to Southend Police Station and asked to be locked up for his and the public’s safety, claiming he was a savage werewolf.The officers on duty were reluctant to put him in the cells after seeing he had no criminal history.But it was at this point that Bill turned, growling and snarling at Duty Sergeant Terry Fisher before grabbing the ft tall,  stone police officer by the throat and throwing him across the station’s car park.Chaos ensued and a total of eight police officers were required to restrain the werewolf man, who was fighting them on all fours.That wasn’t the end of the ordeal though.Bill then used his strength to smash his way through a re-enforced hatch in his cell’s door, managing to get both his arm and head stuck in the opening before he was sedated with a dose nearly three times the amount of an average person.PC Tony Belford said that he’d never seen anything like it before or since - and the news even made The Sun’s front page – earning Bill the nickname of ‘The Southend Werewolf’.On  February , Cannock Chase murderer Raymond Leslie Morris was sentenced to le imprisonment for the rape and murder of seven-year-old Christine Darby.Its widely thought the corpses of Margaret Reynolds, , and Diana Joy Tt, , both found in January  were also linked to the predator.All three bodies were found within a mile of each other in the Staffordshire woodland.And in the very the same area, there have been numerous sightings of the black-eyed ghost of a young girl, leading many to suspect that it might be the spirit of one of Morris’ victims.The first report was in the summer of  when a young woman heard a child frantically shouting for help in Cannock Chase forest.On locating the sound, the woman found a little girl of around six years old on a dirt track.She had completely black eyes with no trace of white, and quickly disappeared into the woodland.More than  years later, another woman had a very similar experience in the haunted forest. “We instantly started running towards the noise,” the eyewitness told the Sunday Mercury.“We couldn’t find the child anywhere and so stopped to catch our breath.”On turning around, she saw a girl of no more than  years old with her hands over her eyes.“She put her arms down by her side and opened her eyes. That’s when I saw they were completely black, no iris, no white, nothing. I jumped back and grabbed my daughter. When I looked again, the child was gone. It was so strange.”Various paranormal experts have since investigated the area, with the YouTube channel Haunted Finders even managing to capture the ghost on camera in .Cemeteries are creepy places. But in the late s and early s there was an added spookiness to the decaying and decrepit Highgate Cemetery in North London, after numerous people reported sightings of a supernatural being.One was made by British Psychic and Occult Society member David Farrant, who wrote a letter to the Hampstead and Highgate Express claiming that he had seen “a grey figure” in the cemetery Christmas Eve .A handful of people claimed that they had also seen a tall, dark figure, floating behind the railings.These reports caught the interest of another local man Sean Manchester – a real-le vampire hunter – who believed that the ghostly figure was that of a Romanian ‘Vampire of the Undead’ that had been brought to England in the early s.Finally, after  years of hunting, Manchester published a book in which he claimed to have successfully staked, beheaded and burnt the vampire.But with no photo evidence, some believe the vampire could still be out there.While the ghost of the young girl in Cannock Chase ran away from people, there have been reports of ghosts who have attacked people in the UK, too.Greyfriars Cemetery in Edinburgh, Scotland, is home to a number of notable names, including Thomas Riddell – the inspiration Voldemort in JK Rowling’s Harry Potter books.But the cemetery is also home to one resident even more chilling than the Dark Lord himself.Sir George ‘Bluid’ MacKenzie was a th century lawyer who is blamed for the deaths of thousands of men during Charles II’s religious persecution of Presbyterians in Scotland - and his ghost still haunts the area to this day.MacKenzie laid undisturbed for more than  years before his spirit was reportedly first encountered in .A homeless man decided to take shelter in MacKenzie’s final resting place – the Black Mausoleum – on a dark and stormy night when something terrying happened.An ancient coffin allegedly collapsed beneath him, plunging him into a pit containing still decomposing plague victims, and the man ran from the scene covered in dust, startling a passerby that was out walking their dog.It is believed that the incident disturbed the spirit of MacKenzie,  and since then there have been more than  recorded incidents of poltergeist attacks on members of the public there.Volunteer guide Willie Telford told Edinburgh Evening News: “People have been bitten, scratched, kicked, pushed, they get burn marks, they feel sick, they feel cold.And it gets worse.Borley Rectory in Essex is widely regarded as ‘the most haunted house in England’.There have been reports of strange incidents at the Victorian house for decades, including sightings of a ghost nun and a phantom coach driven by two headless horsemen.But things really escalated in , when the resident Reverend Guy Eric Smith contacted a national newspaper to report otherworldly activity, including bells ringing and the sound of footsteps.The paper sent paranormal investigator Harry Price to carry out research, and the activity intensied, with reports including the throwing of vases and stones.The Smiths soon left the property, with the reverend’s we believing that Price had been behind it all. But the strange occurrences continued.Smith’s replacement, Reverend Lionel Algernon Foyster, also recorded incidents including bell-ringing, writing appearing on the wall and even his we, Marianne, being thrown from her bed by a poltergeist.The mystery remained unsolved and the house burnt down in  before being completely demolished five years later.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond theresea may budget
story: I know for many, the past few years haven’t been easy. But I’m happy to tell Sun on Sunday readers that their hard work is paying off.Our jobs market has defied many of the naysayers.Near record numbers of people have a job and unemployment has fallen in every region across the country.There are more than .million additional people in work since .While this is a huge achievement, sometimes it’s easy to forget that behind these numbers are thousands of people up and down our country who are now better able to provide for their families.They can get up every morning knowing they have the security that only a job can bring.And what’s more, they are being rewarded with a pay rise — this month’s figures show the strongest wage growth in almost a decade.Contrary to myths peddled by the opposition, it’s people at the bottom of the pay scale who have benefited most.The lowest earners working full-time have seen the fastest rise in pay thanks to our National Living Wage and the proportion of low-paid jobs is at a record low.Tomorrow I will deliver my Budget, where I will show how our careful focus on fixing the economy is bearing fruit.Thanks to the balanced approach we have taken — getting our debt falling, while keeping taxes low — and the hard work of the people of the UK, I will be able to set out how we will be investing in our future.Much of the talk surrounding Budgets is often technical. Many, many experts and commentators will have their own take on how the economy is doing.While this is, of course, important, what most ordinary people really care about is how the Budget will improve their day-to-day lives.And one of the issues which I know Sun on Sunday readers care a lot about is transport. With a thousand more people moving into work every day, it’s important that we help to get them there on time.Many of you preparing to start the working week tomorrow will know the frustration of having your journey to work ruined by delays caused by poorly maintained roads. Or of having your car or van damaged by potholes.This isn’t just a bad way to start the day, it’s bad for businesses large and small, and it can be really damaging to the wider economy as well.It’s estimated that congestion costs UK households more than £billion every year. That’s why tomorrow I will announce a bumper £billion investment in our country’s transport network — including a new £.billion fund ring-fencing vehicle excise duty raised in England for spending on our roads.As a former Transport Secretary, I know that these are the arteries that keep our country alive – and they need taking care of. Thirty-two years ago tomorrow, Margaret Thatcher officially opened the final stretch of the M.While few would claim to love this motorway, it’s easy to forget what a landmark moment this was for our country’s transport infrastructure. Three decades later, I am committed to honouring that legacy.And as important as our major roads are, smaller local roads are just as vital to our everyday lives.That’s why I will also announce tomorrow £million of immediate cash for councils to maintain and improve local roads — fixing potholes, repairing damaged roads and keeping bridges safe and open.A further £million on top of that will help improve local junctions, allowing better access to workplaces, high streets and other community facilities.This is also part of our commitment to bridging the gap between our regions. Those in rural parts of the country should have the same chances to get on in le and not have poor transport connections limiting their potential.The funding will help make journeys quicker and easier, while boosting productivity and improving access.And because I know that not everyone drives, I will also invest in local transport projects which could include new bus, tram and cycling routes.And I will also look to the future by investing in next-generation methods of transport, which could potentially include self-driving shuttle services.Not only could this revolutionise our transport network, it will also help us become a global leader developing future technologies.And finally, as I earlier announced with the Prime Minister, I am happy to confirm we will also be freezing fuel duty, for the ninth year in a row.This will keep the cost of fuel down for millions of drivers across the UK — saving people around £million this year alone.These measures are only possible due to our careful management of the economy over the past few years — and the hard work of the British people.This country has a bright future ahead, and — thanks to this vital investment package — the journey there just got a bit smoother.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellors 13bn budget priti patel
story: The Chancellor is set to announce an unexpected £ billion annual windfall in this week’s budget, which means he won’t have to take away more of what you earn and put up your taxes to fund the extra £ billion a year that has been promised for the NHS by .This is good news for taxpayers and also for our economy, as this is the largest annual change in borrowing forecasts since this data was first produced in  when Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister.And there’s a reason for this windfall. It shows the strength and resilience of the UK economy alongside the efforts and hard work of families and households up and down the country.In conventional times voters might rightly expect the result of this to be lower taxes , more investment in our public services or to see progress in us paying off the ever ballooning national debt.Instead the Government is preparing to blow this cash - your money - by giving into even more of the EU’s demands.Until last week, Britain expected a  month “transition” or “implementation” period after we formally leave the EU next year on March , .Then, late last week the Government shocked everyone by proposing that we stay in the EU longer than we were originally told and that we extend the so called ‘negotiating period’ to leave the EU.Worse still, on Monday in the House of Commons, we were told that this transition period might last until June  – that’s six years after the referendum result. Whatever happened to Brexit means Brexit On top of our extended membership of the EU, we can expect a bill from the EU! That’s right more of your money with an extra price tag of approximately £ billion each year in contributions to the EU.The Treasury has budgeted for this until the end of  but for each year after , the cost will be as high as £ billion because we will have lost the £. billion a year rebate which was famously secured and successfully negotiated in  by Margaret Thatcher when she demanded our money back from the EU.The British people are once again being treated like fools. What we are now witnessing is a blatant attempt to keep Britain in the EU while Brussels continues to raid the pockets of British taxpayers.This must end and the Government should invoke the great Thatcherite spirit of Fontainebleau and say No, No, No to Brussels. Because pumping our money into an undemocratic and unaccountable system two years after Britain voted to leave the EU is simply not right or acceptable. It makes a mockery of our democracy and is an insult to the British public.It is our money and that money should be handed back to the people and communities across the UK to invest in our domestic priorities.It could help people across Britain– especially the least well off – by giving them back more of the money that they earn by cutting their taxes.For example,we cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny, that would cost us £ billion.By increasing the personal allowance by a £,, many more of the poorest paid households would be taken out of tax altogether, that’d cost us £. billion. Andwe cut beer and cider duty by  pence, that would cost us £. billion.So by easing the tax burden for the lowest paid and doing our bit to save British pubs from closing, we’d have invested £ billion into longer term economic growth in our economy.And with the other £ billion  How about supporting the millions of families who want to own their own home by cutting stamp duty for homeowners, we can again help the least well off and give them a hand up and support them in their aspirations to own their home.We could also take more first time buyers out of paying stamp duty altogether  If we raised the starting threshold of £, to £,, this would cost the Treasury £. billion.Then there’s the VAT we pay on domestic gas and electricity. The  per cent VAT charge on domestic fuel and power raised around £. billion in  . If we got rid of this we would make fuel cheaper and families would have a little extra left over in their monthly pay packets.What about the VAT charged on sanitary products for women  This should end now and not when we leave the EU s the Government previously promised, especially as leaving the EU will take longer than we were previously promised. VAT receipts from the sale of sanitary products costs approximately £. billion a year but importantly this one VAT cut that would unite women across the country.I could go on. There are so many important domestic key services and priorities to invest in.To govern is to choose and the choice being made our Government is to spend your money on an expensive and everlasting EU membership.And all this comes on top of the ridiculous capitulation where we have agreed to the EU’s demands to hand over a £ billion pay cheque for absolutely nothing in .Britain needs once again to have a long term economic plan that puts our national interest first.Let’s start standing up for Britain by investing in people, businesses and communities rather than the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats of the European Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. I know you’ve been fingering my Garibaldis.”See. I did warn you.This week’s winner is camp Frank, from The Apprentice, and US outlaw Jesse James.Sent in by Peter Budgen, via email. Picture research Alfie Snelling.This Morning, Rylan Clark-Neal: “Listen, you’re Martine McCutcheon, you’re a living legend.”Strictly, Tess Daly to Doctor Who’s Mandip Gill: “Congratulations on a brilliant series. It’s fantastic, isn’t it ” No.And X Factor, Ayda Field to Scarlett Lee: “You could sing the shopping list and I’d enjoy it.”Then you haven’t seen theof her shopping list.David Haye introducing himself to the winning Apprentice team as “the Hayemaker himself”.Channel  News managing to have a studio discussion about Press injunctions without anyone from the Press.The X Factor pretending Brendan Murray is “a plumber” rather than a professional musician managed by Louis Walsh.Dr Who’s latest right-on brain fart being Donald Trump and grime-loving spiders.And the BBC hiding The Mash Report behind a smokescreen of “satire” when everyone can see it’s simply spouting Auntie’s prejudices against the Tories, Brexit and working-class people.Just in case you weren’t already reminded of them on an almost hourly basis.Will there ever be a charity telethon without the deadening presence of John Bishop How come X Factor drag-act Thomas Pound’s alter-ego wasn’t Thomas Poundland Why did hardly anyone swear in Press  And where the hell did EastEnders’ prisoners all get their amazing suntans They look like they’ve just come off a fortnight’s golf in the Algarve, not a le stretch.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which Elizabethan playwrite wrote A Midsummer Night’s Dream ”Stuart: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Kenneth Clark presented which landmark TV series on the history of art ”Andy: “The Antiques Roadshow.”Ben Shephard: “In which Latin American country is the ancient Mayan temple El Castillo ”Sue: “Egypt.”And Ben Shephard: “Northampton is the county town of which English county ”Kirsty: “Pass.”Jose Mourinho: “If Ronaldo has two touches, he can score a hat-trick.”Phil Thompson: “Elyounoussi is a flash in the pan all the time.”Steve McManaman: “United got a goal back with  minutes left and now it’s -, there’s even more time left.”Compiled by Graham WrayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
