title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. He somehow contrives to make even this chaotic Government look like a model of competence.Budgets often unravel when acres of small print are finally scrutinised.But for now... nice one, Chancellor.ANGELA Merkel is a once-brilliant politician scuppered by an arrogant disregard for voters.For years she was admired worldwide. Then she flooded Germany with a million migrants, enraging the public, fuelling extremism and sealing her own downfall.Don’t expect Brussels to learn from it.Their contempt for citizens is even worse. And it will do for them too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: mum in tears after universal credit blunder leaves her with 74p to live on for a week
story: Melissa Whitchurch, , and her partner Chris Steer,  desperately rummaged around their home looking for things to sell so that they could buy food for their five-year-old daughter Cheyenne - because of a late payment of their benefits.The couple, from Brighton, were expecting a Universal Credit payment of £ to be paid into their bank account last week and planned their finances around it.But when Melissa went to take out the money, she was horried to see her balance was just  pence and called the Department for Work and Pensionshotline for help.Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.Melissa said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks She went on: It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any.Melissa, who is signed off work due to mobility problems, had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one.The family received a payment of £ and were told the other half of that would appear two weeks later.They used the cash to pay off bills and get them food to last the next few weeks, but the other half didnt arrive.Shes just one of many Brits who have had problems with the new benefits system, Universal Credit, which rolls six payments into one.Yesterday the Chancellor revealed that Brits will be able to get more help moving onto Universal Credit - but those changes won’t come in until .Former shop assistant Melissa, who has to take  tablets a day for her health, said: Me and my partner can go without, but not our little girl.If we were told this in the first place, we would have budgeted for it.Its horrible. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness.We try to keep her away from it.But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care.They are heartless.And she avoided going to the food bank for help because she was expecting to be paid on time.Kind strangers and neighbours have been helping her out with food in the meantime.Partner Chris was also signed off work as a chef for mental health reasons.A DWP spokesperson said: The vast majority of claimants are paid in full and on time, and are comfortable managing their money. Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help.Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.

title: ghost hunting apps
story: These are just some of the paranormal phenomena experienced by ghost hunters ft below ground in one of Londons abandoned tube stations.Spectrum Paranormal, a London-based group made up of Hazel F Williams and her nephew Dean, often conducts investigations in South Kentish Town tube station - a building with a spooky history.Originally called Castle Road, the station opened in , but was closed in  due to too few people using it. It has since been nicknamed the ghost tube station.In the s it was rumoured that a commuter, Mr Brackett, met a grisly end there, after becoming trapped when the train stopped and he got off by mistake.No more tubes came and it was locked up, but he couldnt walk on the tracks, says Hazel. Legend has it that he died in there, and his ghost still haunts the station today as he looks for a way out.Spectrum have been conducting investigations since , going into peoples haunted homes to help them with supernatural activity and running public ghost hunting events.Weve done a lot of investigations down here, says Hazel. Weve heard mysterious footsteps, knocking and banging.One day we even made contact with the spirit of a nine-year-old girl who spoke to us, I think she may have died in an accident when the tube station was still in use.While the pro hunters naturally have state of the art equipment, there are plenty of ghost hunting apps available for mobiles.Sun Online went underground with Spectrum for a special Halloween ghost hunt, pitting three iPhone apps against their specialist toolkit.And things certainly got spooky...Could Mr Brackett still be haunting the station today  Thats what Hazel, Dean and Sun Online are hoping to find out with our technology.During previous visits to the station, they have heard what they describe as poltergeist activity, including banging and footsteps, assomebody is trying to find their way out.Theyve also had positive responses when trying out ouija boards in the station.Weve called out his name in the past and got a few replies, him moving the board or knocking says Hazel.The building does have an extremely creepy atmosphere, which is heightened when you know its history.And Dean, who describes himself as a sceptic compared to Hazel who is a full believer in the paranormal, says doing investigations down here has opened his mind to the possibilities that there is something  out there.Hazel and Dean are kitted out with a box full of equipment, such as ious sound recorders, crucixes and even a ouija board, which they have bought from specialist shops and online.Tonight, they will be using a Meterk Meter, which uses an electro-magnetic fieldto seea presence is nearby and a Mel Meter  that measures EMF and temperature:a spirit is present people will often complain of a room going cold.They also have a K meter, which that can allow for communication from spooks by them manipulating the LED lights on the meter.The theory is, your soul carries on within electromagnetic fields, which is how spirits can communicate with us through these items, says Hazel.In Sun Onlines tool box are three iPhone apps.They are: Ghost Hunter M , Ghost Detect Proand Ghost Sensor , which is supposed to imitate the K meter.On first glance, the apps dont seem particularly great. They are packed full of ads, make a lot of weird bleeping noises and seem completely incomprehensible and impossible to use.And Im sceptical as to how an iPhone can even detect ghosts in the first place.When we ask Hazel what she thinks of the apps, she says theyre not as effective for ghost hunting as the experts equipment, as they can be affected by the phones own electrical fields.Shes right: as we walk round, not very much happens with the apps. Ghost Sensor does absolutely nothing, the needle remains still even when Deans K meter starts to spike.When I try out Ghost Detect Pro, I suddenly hear random words coming out of my phone: Wild! Grant! Fish!I wonderthis is a spirit trying to communicate, but Hazel assures me these are often randomised sounds assigned to the app for fun, which is a little bit disappointing.Our final room to try is a corridor with stairs leading up to the next level at the back of it. This, Hazel says, is the place where Spectrum have had the most activity.And it doesnt disappoint: Hazel and Deans equipment starts spiking and bleeping, and even the M app shows the EMF reading is jumping.The room suddenly falls extremely cold, before we hear it: somebody coming down the stairs very slowly, followed by banging sounds.With everyone accounted for, theres surely only one explanation for who it could be...If thats you, knock twice for yes, shouts Dean. And immediately, we hear two knocks coming from the other side of the room.To be honest, its so scary I forget to check my apps, but based on earlier I cant imagine they were doing very much.We wait to heartheres any more, but the weird atmosphere that had been in the room during the knocking lts, and Hazel whispers hes gone.Whether that was Mr Brackett or not, we will never know...Although I cant fully explain the spookiness down in disused station, or the footsteps and knocking we heard, I remain on the fence about ghosts.And as for the apps  Theyre best left to the professionals.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the amazing story of how bluetooth got its name and it goes back centuries
story: But even though we all use it and know the technology product as a household name, where does the name Bluetooth come from It turns out the term actually comes from centuries ago - from King Harald Bluetooth who united Denmark and Norway in the th century.His nickname Bluetooth was deemed appropriate for the new piece of technology back in the s due to King Harald having brought two nations together - as the technology was designed to do with electronic devices.Bluetooth enables information and data to be passed from one electronic device to another at short range without a physical connection.The reason for King Haralds unusual nickname was that he had a dead tooth which was a dark blue grey colour.Initially Bluetooth was intended to be an internal code name while the technology was being fully developed, but when the other options pitched by the marketing team were either too unoriginal or couldnt be be patented in time for the release date, they settled with what they had.The Bluetooth logo is a combination of King Haralds initials in rune: ᚼand ᛒ .Susie Dent, Countdowns woman in Dictionary Corner, tweeted this fact earlier today and excited fans with the revelation.She writes: This will be familiar to many, but I love the fact that Bluetooth technology owes its name to a th century ruler - one King Harald Bluetooth, who united Denmark and Norway. His nickname was thought appropriate for technology that brings devices together.Others contributed their own knowledge about the subject, one writing: Harald Gormsson, or Harald Bluetooth, lived in the th century and introduced Christianity to Denmark and ruled over what is now Denmark, northern Germany, southern Sweden and parts of Norway. His nickname came from the fact he had a dead tooth that looked bluish.Others joked about the reliability of Bluetooth: Did King Harald also have pairing problems: unable to pair when too far and pairing with random devices when too close.While one Twitter user joked about an alternative name for Brexit: And one day, through back construction, the Shambles York will be rembered as being named to commemorate Brexit.

title: can you spot the venomous snake hidden in this familys garden
story: The person panicked and thought they saw a brown snake lurking near their garage in Queensland, Australia, so phoned for help.Christian Andersen, who works for local firm South Burnett Snake Catchers  , was called out and confirmed it was a venomous yellow faced whip snake.But he has also issued a warning after an image appeared to show the snake tucked underneath rocks and a small bridge in the garden.This particular species is dubbed the “cheetahs of the snake world” because they can move at lightning speed.They are often mistaken from brown snakes which can be deadly because of their venom.But he also highlighted how discreet they can be because he said the snake is not obvious to see with the naked eye.Christian told Yahoo: “It was a yellow faced whip snake going just by the scales alone.“Their venom isnt considered to be dangerous to humans. People can still suffer an anaphylactic reaction to the bite so medical treatment still shouldnt be dismissed.”He added that the reptiles can be mistaken for “juvenile common brown snakes” and they typically hide in people’s gardens.

story: Trick-or-treaters are advised to head out early before heavy downpours drench areas up and down the country.And it looks like the rain will begin fairly early on in the evening at around pm for many parts of Britain after a broadly dry and mild afternoon.A Met Office spokesperson said of the rain: It’s moving across from the West and the South West and it’s basically moving slowly eastwards across the whole of the country.On the western side, you’re likely to catch a shower any time really, but it’s moving gradually soyou go out earlier the further East you are, the less likely it is that you’ll get hit by the stuff coming later.But theres also another area of rain and showers moves into northern England and Wales early on this evening.The inclement conditions will continue towards the end of the week as Hurricane Oscar is set to bring mph winds and mm of rain to the UK when it hits on Friday.Today will be a frosty morning for most with widespread freezing temperatures.Showers will mainly fall in the West as sunny spells are enjoyed in much of Wales, England, and Eastern Scotland.And in the afternoon we could see temperatures into the double figures with highs of around C in the South and  in the North.Therell be a spooky start in Northern Ireland tomorrow morning as dense fog covers much of the country.And tonights rain will carry on into Thursday, as persistent showers fall across central and south eastern parts of England while there will be lighter showers in Scotland.And Friday will start with a good deal of sunshine for many before turning very wet and windy in the North West as the effects of Hurricane Oscar strike Britain.

title: meghan markle fan instagram new zealand
story: The Duchess of Sussex was doing a public walkabout at the Viaduct Harbour in Auckland when she recognised -year-old Hannah Sergel on Tuesday.Cameras captured the moment Meghans jaw visibly dropped as she mouthed Oh my God and made her way over to give the shaking student a hug.The pair were friends on Instagram before the Duchess deleted her account following her engagement to Prince Harry - but had never met in person.Before deactivating her social media page, the -year-old would send Hannah motivational messages encouraging her to be herself and do well at university.Meghan, who is pregnant with her first child, even sent her a video clip in  personally thanking her for her support and telling her she hoped to meet her soon.And that moment finally happened on Tuesday as Hannah, who had flown across the country, stood with thousands of Royal fans hoping to catch a glimpse of the newlyweds.She was holding a sign that said: Its Hannah from Instagram, when the former Suits star noticed her.Hannah told New Zealands  News: “She said ‘thank you for getting in touch,’ and then she gave me a hug and said she would read my letter that I gave her.“I was friends with her on Instagram before she had to deactivate her account. We used to have conversations and stuff on there. She would tell me to do well at university and encourage me to be myself.”Hannah, who was shaky and flustered during their brief encounter, added that it “means the world” to her that Meghan had recognised her.She told Honey: She recognised me and knew who I was so thats why she came over.She gave me a hug which was incredible - when I first saw her I cried. Shes just such an incredible person and Im just so glad shes happy with Harry.The student was even comforted by New Zealand prime minister Jacinda Ardern afterwards because she had started crying and was such a mess.Incredibly, the politician later sent her a direct message on Twitter with a photo of the special moment.Recounting how she finally met her idol with her followers, Hannah said: Can you believe Meghan Markle held me with both her hands then went in for a hug. Im still in shock.Meghan said come here before hugging me.Hannah was a fan long before the Duchess even met Harry and co-founded the Meghan Markle Daily Twitter account in .It was the penultimate day of the Royal couples marathon -day tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand.

title: bbc sport dan roan off air leicester city owner
story: Dan Roan was caught questioning Vichai Srivaddhanaprabhas relationship with his PA and ex-Miss Thai Universe runner-up after they were killed in a helicopter crash.The recording was picked up on a Sky News live feed streaming on YouTube from outside Leicester FCs King Power Stadium, where the helicopter crashed on Saturday.He later tweeted to apologise for the comments made on Monday, but was notably absent from the BBCs coverage of the tragedy in Leicester the next day.The corporation has refused to confirm whether Roan would face disciplinary action, saying: “We deal with staff matters privately.”A BBC spokesperson said: “This was an ill-judged comment made in a private off-air conversation for which Dan has apologised.”But a source told the : “The BBC have taken a dim view of this. They told him at the outset that the main thing he needed to do was to strike the right tone, and then this happens.”Roan was standing just yards from the crash site where thousands had come to lay flowers, including Vicahi’s we Aimon and son Aiyawatt, when he made the comment about Nursara Suknamai, who was also killed in the crash.He was overheard saying: The mistress who died in the crash… otherwise known as a member of staff…i.e. mistress.“If you were a billionaire, it’s relatively expected, so we shouldn’t judge.”The recording was later posted online and hundreds of football fans slammed Roan’s remarks.One wrote: It doesnt matter that it was private, or off-air, you were stood  yards away from his memorial.So disrespectful, so thoughtless and hurtful.On Monday afternoon Roan tweeted: “Just want to say sorry for some comments made in a private, off-air conversation earlier with a colleague. Absolutely no offence intended.But his apology was met with backlash from fans who called for him to resign.One supported described the remarks as thoughtless and hurtful, while another said: If you had an iota of contrition, you would tender your resignation.Roan, from Northampton, has been the sports editor for the BBC since September .He joined the corporation in the s and has previously held the roles of Chief Sports Correspondent and Sports News Correspondent.Roan was given an honorary degree by the University of Northampton in July this year.Tributes flooded in for Mr Srivaddhanaprabha and the other victims of the horror crash following Saturday’s match against West Ham United.Police confirmed the others who died were employees Nursara Suknamai and Kaveporn Punpare, pilot Eric Swaffer and his partner Izabela Roza Lechowicz, who was also a professional pilot.It comes as Leicester City players joined Vichais family in paying a tearful tribute to the club owner on Monday.Players - including striker Jamie Vardy and goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel - held back tears as they stood by Vichais son Aiyawatt at the memorial.Aiyawatt wept as he lay a floral tribute today among of a sea of wreaths and well-wishes left by fans of the club, joined by Vichais sobbing we.

story: A section on Swim Englands website included guidelines on how female swimmers shouldnt squeeze into swimsuits - while women with boyish figures were advised to try push-up cups to enhance their figures.Simone Webb, a PhD student in gender studies,  said she had been thinking of getting back into swimming and had gone to Swim Englands website to find out more.Instead she found a series of outdated tips on what women should apparently aspire to look like in the pool.She tweeted: @Swim_England apparently think that a boyish body needs to be feminized, that fat women must minimize their bodies, that women wanting to take up swimming should be concerned with their bodily appearance rather than the enjoyment of their sport.Some of the advice included snippets such as: Bikinis totally expose a jiggly belly, and trying to squeeze into a one-piece will not slim your stomach, only emphasize it.The author also thought to add their thoughts on the pear body shape, writing: A pear shape has often been the plague of women, but it no longer needs to be so.Ms Webb added: I feel like Ive become pretty jaded and seen-it-all regarding sexism, but this has genuinely shocked me.Swim England has since removed the article and apologised, saying it contained old information.A spokesperson told BBC Sport: This was an old web page from  that does not represent the views of Swim England. As soon as the article was brought to our attention we removed the page and are in the process of replacing it with more appropriate information.Swimming is one of the most accessible activities for people of all ages and abilities. We want everyone to feel comfortable in the water so they can take advantage of the many benefits swimming has to offer.We apologise for any offence this old information may have caused and hope this wont deter people from continuing to enjoy the water.

title: baby faced car thief mowed down cop pictured rolls royce
story: One-man crimewave Kash Parkinson, , has been jailed after racing away in a stolen Ford Fiesta which he had fitted with  plates on June .Parkinson is seen driving on the wrong side side of a dual carriageway at .am before ramming into an oncoming HGV.The thug, from Ashton-under-Lyne in Tameside, Greater Manchester, injured the hero policeman who was trying to detain him during a pursuit.PC Christopher Haxby jumped out and tried to grab Parkinson but the teenager reversed the Fiesta. As a result the officer was propelled backwards into the bonnet of the police car.Despite his head hitting the windscreen PC Haxby bravely got back to his feet and managed to open the Fiesta door and drew his Taser to detain Parkinson.The officer suffered with whiplash and back pain and has been forced to take time off work. Cost of damage to the police car, Ford Fiesta and the HGV was estimated at a total of £,.In an earlier incident Parkinson and a group of friends stole a disabled mans Renault Scenic along with his disability scooter which was in the boot.Police chased him again and blocked in the stolen car in a suburban street where children were playing but Parkinson drove up on to the pavement, narrowly missing a child, before driving off at speed and losing the officers.The Renault was found days later completely written off, and the disability scooter was also damaged to the stage it was deemed redundant.Fed-up residents reported Parkinson for repeated car and motorbike thefts and he was also arrested for drugs offences, assault, vandalism and even terrorising his own grandmother.JPs placed him on youth rehabilitation schemes and also banned him from his regular haunts and associating with other yobs.But Parkinson simply ignored a two-year Criminal Behaviour Order - even booking taxis to meet his cronies.When he was placed in a care home away from his family he threatened to shoot and stab his care workers.The young thug would also post pictures of himself smoking suspicious-looking cigarettes on social media and he even spelt his own name in cannabis leaves.Parkinson could barely see over the steering wheel of the Phantom supercar which was parked near his home - but still posed for pictures after hopping into the drivers seat.In court Parkinson yawned and stretched his arms over-dramatically as he listened to the proceedings. He admitted assault occasioning actual bodily harm, aggravated vehicle taking, dangerous driving, driving while disqualied and twice breaching a criminal behaviour.Judge Mark Savill told him: “You have shown a lack of respect for the police and a lack of remorse and you have expressed no desire to change. So I must put the protection of the public and a punishment for you first.”He added: Youre just  but have an appalling record and the footage of the pursuit I have seen is truly chilling. Many people have the good sense to lie when they say they want to change their ways, but you have no idea.“That police officer could have been killed because of your selfishness. It is a wonder how you didn’t kill or seriously injure a member of the public or a police officer.“Your pre-sentence report makes a depressing read.“I know you have dficulties in your le but you have indicated a lack of remorse and have expressed no desire to change.“You present a high risk of reoffending.“I am not going to impose a sentence that will crush any hope you have - but you cannot reoffend like this.”Parkinson was also disqualied from driving for five years. He has a large number of previous convictions starting from when he was just  for offences including vehicle crime, dishonesty, assaults on a police and public disorder offences.His lawyer Mark Fireman said in mitigation: “This is somebody who has had one of the worst starts in le.“He has been left with many dficulties. He is physically immature and emotionally extremely immature. He has been in care for many years. He has had minimal parental input.He is essentially bringing himself up.When one does that outside the control from an older person, the sense of what is right and wrong is extremely blurred.This young mans record is appalling but he just hasn’t grown up yet emotionally.

title: universal credit budget changes
story: The major changes revealed by Philip Hammond this week to the new flagship system won’t come in for months, and are set to exclude some groups.The Chancellor said he would increase the work allowance for those on Universal Credit by £, meaning working Brits, or those who are disabled can keep £ extra every year of their own money.But Brits on benefits are only eligible for a work allowancethey have kids or have a limited capacity for work. .million are expected to get a boost.The work allowances are £ a monthyour benefits includes housing support, or £ without it.But respected announced by George Osborne in  – though not for the childless non-disabled.“Their work allowances were cut to zero in  and there they remain.”Labour’s John McDonnell said today there was “nothing for Universal Credit recipients who are single and without children”.Households on the minimum wage, working full-time with with no dependent children are still expected to be £ worse off than they were in , think tanks estimated.Changes set to come in in  will mean Brits will be able to get an extra two weeks of benefits from Jobseeker’s Allowance, ESA and Income Support as a result of yesterday’s researcher at Bright Blue warned: “Despite these welcome changes to Universal Credit, many low-income families will continue to face a signicant squeeze on their real incomes thanks to unnecessary and deep cuts to working-aged benefits. title: brexit deal latest theresa may brussels aides eu talks
story: Dominic Raab told MPs he expects the Brexit deal to be finalised by November , adding: The end is now firmly in sight.The pound soared as the news emerged today in a letter from Mr Raab to Hilary Benn, chair of the Commons Brexit committee.Negotiations between the UK and EU formally restarted in Brussels this week, raising hopes of a possible deal.Today Mr Benn published a letter sent by Mr Raab last week in which the minister predicted a deal would be done soon.He wrote: I would be happy to give evidence to the committee when a deal is finalised, and currently expect November  to be suitable.Mr Raab added: The end is now firmly in sight and, while obstacles remain, it cannot be beyond us to navigate them.We have resolved most of the issues and we are building up together what the future relationship should look like and making real progress.He said the main outstanding issue to be resolved in talks is the Northern Ireland backstop which is meant to rule out checks on the Irish border.No envoy Olly Robbins is meeting top Eurocrats this week - in a bid to strike an agreement as quickly as possible.The PM has been hoping to cut a deal in time for an emergency Brexit summit which could be held in mid-November.Mrs May wants to cut a deal based on her Chequers plan, which would see Britain continue to follow European rules for goods while setting new regulations on services.She could face a challenge getting the agreement through the House of Commons - but last night Tory rival David Davis suggested she would succeed.The ex-Brexit Secretary predicted MPs would be so scared of No Deal they might back whatever Mrs May proposed.Speaking at a think-tank event, he said: Terror will win. The fear of No Deal, I think - we havent had a chance to talk about it much - but I think thats an irrational fear of No Deal or WTO deal. That will win and there will be a deal.But a friend told The Sun: DD didnt mean PM WILL get a deal through Parliament, but MUST get a deal through Parliament.“He inferred she would secure a deal rather than a No Deal - but only Canada can get through, not Chequers.”Pressure on the Government to strike a deal could increase following a report that Britain will fall into recession without one.Rating agency SP today warned that a No Deal scenario would cause a spike in unemployment and inflation, as well as a house price crash.The firm predicted household incomes would fall by £, in the year after Britain left the EU without a withdrawal deal.More than , UK residents a month are applying to become citizens of the Republic of Ireland.Irish senator Neale Richmond said: Figures for the first half of  show the number of applications received by the embassy in London is already at ,.Embassy officials predict that based on this,  will be the busiest year so far for Irish passport applications in the UK.While many in the UK are concerned with the looming disaster of Brexit, we must seize the positives from this new wave of people reconnecting with their Irish heritage, our post-Brexit UK-Irish relations can be built on a strong, connected, diaspora.Before the Brexit referendum in , only half as many British people were applying for Irish passports.The figures dont include residents of Northern Ireland, who are automatically eligible for an Irish passport as well as a UK one.

story: Engineering works are set to wreak havoc on millions trying to head home over the festive break, with routes from Glasgow to Penzance erted, delayed or cancelled entirely.Trains across the UK will grind to a halt on Christmas Day, with only a fraction of services running on Boxing Day.Disruption will spread across the festive period though, with major engineering works being carried out from December  to January  - sparking  days of chaos.Crossrail works at London Paddington station are likely to cause the most disruption, with most routes axed over the festive period.London Euston station, which links the capital with Birmingham New Street and Manchester Piccadilly, will also be hit by changes to a number of its routes.While rail replacement buses will be in place between Liverpool Lime Street and Crewe to cope with the closure of Warrington train station over this period.Holidaymakers trying to leave the country also face issues - the Gatwick Express will run from other Central London stations while works are carried out at Victoria, and no TfL will run to Heathrow.While many train operators are yet to announce exactly how and passengers will face disruption, Blackpool, Leicester, Nottingham and Warrington will be among the stations affected.Last year Brits were also hit by rail chaos, with closures and cancellations affecting millions of passengers over the festive period.Millions more took to the roads, and were hit by hour-long tailbacks both before and after Christmas.

title: universal credit grenfell tower christmas
story: Families who suffered through last years deadly fire will be switched to Universal Credit in mid-December.The move raises the prospect of claimants suffering gaps in their payments over Christmas.Thousands of Brits claiming the new Universal Credit, which replaces six dferent benefits, have seen their income shrink as a result.Ministers have been urged to step in and protect Grenfell survivors who could miss out as a result of the utterly heartless switchover.UC will be rolled out to the North Kensington area, which includes the Grenfell neighbourhood, on December .Residents who make a new benefits claim, or who have to register a change in circumstances, will be put on UC.Other locals can stay on the existing benefits scheme for longer as long as their work and family situation remains the same.Universal Credit is paid monthly and in arrears - meaning anyone switching to the scheme must wait five weeks for their first payment, unless they apply for an emergency loan from the Government.Labour MP David Lammy blasted: This is utterly heartless.  Grenfell families are still in temporary accommodation following the fire that killed  of their neighbours.The Government should make special assurances that survivors are not pushed into destitution over Christmas.A spokesman for the Department for Work and Pension said: “The Grenfell fire was a horric tragedy and our thoughts remain with those affected.“Following last year’s events, DWP jobcentre staff handled people’s claims with sensitivity and flexibility and extra support was put in place for anyone who needed it.“The timetable for Universal Credit rollout has been available for some time and is on track for completion in December .”This week Philip Hammond announced he was pumping an extra £.billion a year into UC in a bid to fix the problems which have plagued the system.

story: And then, just as we were getting used to Raksriaksorn, it changed again to something even more unpronounceable. title: free holiday prize came 5000
story: NewsFree holiday prize came with a £, sting in the taleSales sharks from Xfinity Sands SL prey on tourists in travel hot spotShareCommentsByAndrew Penman:,  OCT NewsLanzarote: beware of sharks "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf ever you wanted a reason to ignore those touts that collar you on holiday, insisting that youve won a great prize, here it is. Heather Pollard and her friend Ian OConnor were enjoying a winter break in the Canary Islands when they decided to visit a nearby market. That meant booking tickets from a tour shop next to their hotel in Costa Teguise, Lanzarote. While they were there some prize draw tickets were thrust into their hands. Heather won a toy camel and Ian apparently had hit the jackpot, winning a weeks holiday. To collect the prizes they had to go into the office of a business called Xfinity Sands SL. “That was a fatal mistake,” Heather, , was to say later. A sales rep called Mark Holden “began to give us the hard sell”, Heather recalls, adding: “It was so intense that I began to wonder how I could get out of there.” Xfinity Sands turned out to be a sales agent for Mtas.eu, which describes itself as “an internet-based discount club” offering “a very simple but unique holiday concept”.  It promises all sorts of cheap deals but these are dficult to very because you have to join before you can log into its website. “It just kept on and on, Ian was getting agitated,” said Heather. “Hed being seeing the memory clinic over a number of months and had become more and more forgetful and more stressed in dficult situations.” There wasnt even any respite when she asked to use the toilet, one of Holdens colleagues escorted her there and back. Eventually, she says, “I decided to sign just to get out”, paying a pound deposit by credit card to join Mtas. The prize toy camel and free holiday never materialised, though the pair were given free tickets for the market.  “We shot out of the room and breathed a sigh of relief,” said Heather. “I knew that it was a mistake. I tried to cancel after ing to the hotel but my bank said the transaction had gone through. “I ed to Mark Holdens office but it was closed. “I didnt even use the tickets to the market as I was so sick at what had happened.” When back home in Hornsea, East Yorkshire, Heather got hold of Mr Holden by telephone, only to be told that there was no cooling off period. She pointed out that Ian, , had been diagnosed with dementia. Holden replied – andthis is true it it beyond disgusting – that they could still take the holidays “just bring nappies for him”. He added thatshe didnt pay the balance of pound, for one years membership of Mtas then hed put debt collectors onto her. And he did. Last month Heather received a letter from Daniels Silverman, which boasts “We’re regarded as one of the top debt collection and credit management companies in the UK.” Daniels Silverman demanded payment within seven days “to avoid the possibility of further action being taken against you”.

title: gemma collins comes face face
story: NewsRevealed: What Gemma Collins and Jeremy Corbyn discussed in THAT unlikely meetingGemma Collins said she wanted to help spread Corbyns manesto and make Labour ideas “easier to understand”ShareCommentsByAshleigh Rainbird:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsGemma Collins was ecstatic to meet Jeremy Corbyn "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Pride of Britain red carpet played host to a meeting of minds when Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn met TOWIE’s Gemma Collins. The JC and the GC, together at last. Now, Gemma has volunteered her services to help spread Corbyn’s manesto to a wider audience. “It was a magical moment,” says Gemma - whose dad is a “lelong” Labour supporter.“He said it was a pleasure to meet me, and that he liked my dress - he obviously loved it that I was wearing red. “It was like When Harry Met Sally.”  Gemma, who is impressed by Corbyn’s youth appeal, is a passionate supporter of several of his key polices and wants to help him make them “easier to understand”. “He thinks Britain’s railways should be rationalised* - that’s a good thing,” she says. “He’s not just for the rich getting rich. He wants to make everything equal. “He’s got values on education, and he says every child should learn a musical instrument - that’s about giving children something to do, so they’re not hanging around on the streets.” Gemma describes her new friend as “engaging and charming”, and credits Corbyn with being a man of his word because he prefers a trusty red bike to a car.  “At his age now - I’m not saying he’s old, old - the fact that he’s out there riding a bicycle and he doesn’t have a car... a lot of people say they’ve got beliefs. But he actually backs what he says.” Most importantly, Gemma approves of his NHS support. “Do you know why I love Jeremy  He wants to end hospital car parking charges. “I’m not being funny, but someone’s died - a member of your family - and you’ve gotta put three quid in the meter It’s just not the time. Your mum has a heart attack, yet you’ve got to rustle around in your bag for pound  It’s not the one.” This could be the start of a beautul friendship.Gemma, who participated in ’s No Vote No Voice campaign, adds: “I want to go to lunch with him.I’m not finished with Corbyn - he’s inspired me. He’s always saying let’s build a fairer Britain... let’s make a change.”

title: jeremy corbyn john mcdonnell face
story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell face some taxing questions: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Labour leadership is hit with a backlash after refusing to reverse Philip Hammonds tax cutsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT NewsopinionJohn McDonnell and Jeremy Corbyn have taken a controversial position on tax "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email All politics is about choices. As Nye Bevan once said “the language of priorities is the religion of socialism.” In his Budget on Monday Philip Hammond made clear his priorities and he definitely wasn’t praying at the altar of socialism. When presented with the choice of cutting taxes for the wealthy or helping those on the lowest incomes, he went for the former . Presented with the choice of handing high earners more than pound a year or ending the welfare freeze, he went for the former. Presented with the choice of cutting corporation tax or additional funding for education, the police and local government, he went for the former. Which made it remarkable that John McDonnell yesterday said Labour would not reverse the income tax measures in the Budget even though % of the tax cuts will benefit the top half of earners. Andy Burnham was one of many Labour figures to warn McDonnell’s position would not hold. The Greater Manchester mayor said he could not see how tax cuts for the wealthiest could be the priority when the police were so stretched and there are “people dying on British streets for want of a roof over their head.” Many Labour MPs also voiced concerns. Jess Phillips put it succinctly in a tweet this morning: “When Philip Green gets more from the budget than a midwe might I suggest we are on sh**ty ground.” The Shadow Chancellor, who is meeting business leaders today, is showing a pragmatism that comes with the challenge of seeking power. But you cannot help thinking thata previous Labour leadership had adopted this position he would have been one of the first to object. Even when Hammond made the right choice - the additional funding for the NHS - it fell short of what is required. As the IFS noted yesterday, the lt in NHS spending amounts to an increase of .% a year which is below the average increases of .% a year over the NHS’s entire history and the % a year over the period of the last Labour government.

title: labour vow end benefits freeze
story: NewsLabour promise to end benefits freeze hit by confusion after new comments by Jeremy Corbyns spokesmanLabour WILL halt the Tories cruel four-year freeze on welfare payments - but a spokesman clashed with journalists over the detailShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe comments by Jeremy Corbyns spokesman appeared to contradict John McDonnell "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabours vow to end the benefits freeze was thrown into confusion today after new comments by Jeremy Corbyns spokesman. The spokesman insisted Labour WILL halt the Tories cruel four-year freeze on welfare payments - which takes poundbillion a year from the pockets of the nations poorest. But he did NOT confirm Labour will raise benefits every year in line with inflation. Campaigners saythis doesnt happen, it will be a real-terms cut - continuing the pain for millions of families. The spokesmans comments appeared to contradict both Labours shadow chancellor and its welfare chief. UPDATE: The comments have now been claried since we published this story. A spokesman told us: Our commitment is to end the social security freeze and uprate in line with inflation.  John McDonnell told the Mirror only last week that Labour would uprate benefits with inflation. Askeduprating benefits with inflation every year was the specic policy, the Shadow Chancellor told us: Yes, that’s what we’ve said. He later added: We’re saying we’re uprating. Labours Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary has also told the Mirror she would uprate benefits with inflation. Margaret Greenwood told us last month: We would end the benefits freeze, and that would mean uprating in line with inflation every year.  But today, Mr Corbyns spokesman said raising benefits with inflation was a dferent issue to Labours confirmed policy of ending the freeze. Instead, he said the definition of ending the freeze was you start to increase benefits again. He added ending a freeze can mean turning on the temperature to dferent degrees. Asked directlya rise could be less than inflation, he said: Exactly how that will be spelt out in the next manesto and the exact commitment is part of that review [of benefits]. But that we will end the benefits freeze is a commitment.  Speaking at a briefing for Westminster journalists, he added: A freeze means you dont increase anything. If you move off it, the freeze has ended. Cruel Tories have frozen benefit rates for four years to slash pound.billion a year from the welfare bill by  . A Labour spokesman later issued a new statement clarying the partys position. He said: Our commitment is to end the social security freeze and uprate in line with inflation.  The exchange in full JOURNALIST: Just to get the meaning clear, will a Labour government uprate benefits every year in line with inflation  JEREMY CORBYNS SPOKESMAN: Thats a dferent issue, weve said we- Its not, thats exactly what ending the benefits freeze is, so is that what Labour will do  The commitment to end the freeze is to move off the freeze, that means you start to increase benefits again. It could be partially defrosted  The freeze - its a switch on or off. A freeze means off. If you turn it on, you can turn it on to dferent degrees. But anyway...  So it wouldnt necessarily be in line with inflation, it could be less than inflation  Thats the point John was referring to, exactly how that will be spelt out in the next manesto and the exact commitment is part of that review, but that we will end the benefits freeze is a commitment. I asked John McDonnell last week whether Labour would uprate benefits in line with inflation every year and he said yes. So was he wrong  Im confused, Im genuinely confused. The point Im making is the commitment to end the freeze is there, the exact form that the restructuring of the benefits system, including Universal Credit, is going to take under our policies - only some elements of that have been spelt out. And its subject to a wider review. But that we are going to move off it and end the freeze is a commitment. Later, a Labour spokesman claried: Our commitment is to end the social security freeze and uprate in line with inflation. The mechanism for our restructuring of the social security system and costings will be laid out in our next manesto.

title: tory mp calls labour aide
story: NewsTory MP calls for Labour aide and son of shadow minister who took £ of drugs to Bestival to lose his Commons passIshmael Osamor works as a communications aide for his mum Kate OsamorShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video tory-mp-calls-labour-staffer-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory MP has called for a Labour aide and son of shadow minister who took pound of drugs to a music festival to lose his House of Commons pass. Ishmael Osamor, who resigned as a Labour councillor on Tuesday night, admitted three charges of possessing drugs with intent to supply and a fourth charge of possession at last years Bestival event in Dorset. The -year-old works for his mum who is shadow secretary of state for International Development Kate Osamor. He was caught with ecstasy, cocaine, ketamine and cannabis at the music festival in August , nine months before he was elected as a councillor. In his resignation letter his insisted his friends and family were unaware of the charges - including his mum who spoke in his favour during the selection process when he was picked as a Labour council cabinet. Today Tory MP Simon Hoare expressed concern that someone convicted of drugs offences was able to hold on to his parliamentary pass which gives him access to the Houses of Parliament - but he did not name Mr Osamor. He said: We are all alert to the scourge of drugs in our towns and cities. But I also think the House would agreethe sins of the father and the mother cant be visited on the sons then the same is true but in reverse. Raising a point of order MrHoare said: But there is a case, as youll be aware, currently alive and alert in the media about passholders, or a passholder of this place, which is after all an honour not a right, who has been found guilty of drugs-related crime. He asked what the procedure was for examining whether the pass should be taken away.  The Speaker John Bercow told MPs that it was up to him whether staff were able to keep their passes after such an issue had been raised. But Mr Bercow reminded MPs that ideally any complaint would be raised privately. Osamor, who was elected in May to Haringey council, apologised for the unwanted attention his case had brought. He was sentenced to a two-year community order and  days rehabilitation, last Friday. According to expenses records filed with the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority website, his role as Kate Osamors communications officer paid between pound, and pound, in  . In a statement to the councils chief executive he said: It is with great regret that I am offering this as formal notice of my resignation as councillor, effective immediately. I would like to take the opportunity to apologise to the council, as I have to my ward colleagues and residents, for the unwelcome attention my case has brought to Haringey. Councillor Joseph Ejiofor, council leader, said: Councillor Osamor came to see me on Friday  October and explained about an incident that happened in September last year. I expressed my concern and disappointment by the actions that he had admitted. The Labour Party expects high standards from its elected representatives, and I know that Councillor Osamor has taken some personal time over the past four days to review whether his actions have met this expectation. Consequently, Ishmael has decided to resign from Haringey Council. We respect his decision.

title: baby faced teen who posed
story: NewsBaby-faced teen who posed joyriding in Rolls Royce yawns as hes locked up for running over police officerKash Parkinson sent the officer flying onto the bonnet of his stolen car and a court in Manchester heard how he could have been killedShareCommentsByJohn ScheerhoutAmy WalkerDanya Bazaraa:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsKash Parkinson who bragged about his le of joyriding and posed in the drivers seat of a Rolls RoyceLtd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby-faced teen who posed joyriding in a pound, Rolls Royce yawned as he was locked up for reversing into a police officer.Defiant pictures show Kash Parkinson, , shamelessly bragging about his le of joyriding from the drivers seat of the luxury Phantom supercar.At ft ins, he was so small he could barely see over the steering wheel of the vehicle which was parked in a modest terraced street near his home in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester.He has proved a massive headache for police and locals due to the misery he has brought to his neighbourhood. Parkinson, who has an appalling record amassed since he was just eleven, also posted bragging pictures of himself smoking suspicious looking cigarettes on social media and spelt his own name in cannabis leaves.  Yesterday he began a sentence at a young offenders institution for another string of offences, including reversing a stolen Fiesta into a police officer who was trying to catch him. Parkinson stretched and yawned loudly as he was handed a four-year sentence at Manchesters Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester Evening News reports.Describing how Parkinson had reversed into the police officer, the judge said: You tried to get past and rammed into the front of the lorry. The very brave police officer, doing what police officers do on behalf of decent members of society, got out and tried to approach you. What did you do  You reversed. The door was open and caught him, sending him flying onto the bonnet of his car. What he must have been wondering at that time one can only imagine. The court heard how the police officer could have been killed. Parkinson had amassed  previous convictions for  crimes from the age of , the court heard.This included twice assaulting police officers as well as robbery, violence, theft of vehicles and flouting court orders. His defence barrister told the court Parkinson had one of the worst starts in le I have seen and is extremely immature for his age. The judge said he accepted what the teenagers barrister said, but added that there comes a time when the public has to be protected. Parkinsons name and face were earlier published on October , , when he was made the subject of a criminal behaviour order which banned him from the Smallshaw estate in Tameside and disqualied him from driving until . The order made little effect.  On May , this year, he stole a specially-adapted Renault Scenic, which carried on board a mobility scooter and was owned by a disabled man. The owner thought he had lost the keys and had called for roadside assistance, but then saw Parkinson and his young male friends get in the car, with the keys, start the engine and drive away. The car was spotted in the Smallshaw estate that night, with residents reporting a car was screaming around the streets while children were out playing, prosecutor Jon Close told the court. Police patrols gave chase but the stolen Scenic mounted the pavement, narrowly missed a child and sped away, the judge heard. Patrols managed to stop the badly damaged car after it was spotted being driven recklessly again, but the occupants fled.  The car had to be written off and the mobility scooter was also damaged. Parkinson was arrested, charged and appeared before magistrates who released him on bail on June  - a decision described as astonishing by the judge because of his appalling criminal record. It was while on bail - and also on licence for another crime - he went on to commit more and worse crimes. Within three weeks of being released, on June , Parkinson was spotted at the wheel of a stolen Ford Fiesta which he drove at speeds topping mph around Tameside in an attempt to escape the law. The pursuit was captured by a dash camera mounted in the pursuing police car and the footage was played in court. It showed the Fiesta speeding in Ashton-under-Lyne but being forced to stop because a civic-minded HGV driver, who was coming from the opposite direction, used his vehicle to block any escape. PC Christopher Haxby is seen getting out of his patrol car to arrest the driver but Parkinson simply reverses, smashing the open door of the Fiesta into the officer, propelling the bobby onto the bonnet of his own vehicle.  The brave cop is seen to pick himself up, draw his Taser stun gun and order the occupants from the vehicle. He is heard shouting: Get out! Get on the f***ing floor now. Parkinson ran away but was arrested after a brief foot-chase, although he tried to claim during his police interview that he had not been the driver of the Fiesta. The damage caused to the police patrol car was estimated at pound,, while the stolen Fiesta required repairs costing pound,. The HGV had been damaged to the tune of pound,. PC Haxby suffered whiplash as well as injuries to his right leg and shoulder. He could have been killed, noted Judge Martin Savill. After brief details of Parkinsons criminal record were read out, the judge went on: That to me sums up this young mans approach to le. He couldnt care less. He associated with children rather than youths his own age, the court heard. The report describes him as effectively bringing himself up, said Mr Fireman.  Addressing the defendant, who appeared in court via video-link, Judge Savill said he accepted what the barrister said but added that there comes a time when the public has to be protected. This young mans record for one his age is so that it passes beyond the bounds of appalling, said Mr Fireman, while the judge noted that the defendant had unashamedly told probation workers he was unwilling to change. A judge slammed Parkinsons quite appalling criminal record. He sent Parkinson to a young offenders institution for four years and disqualied him from driving for five years. I can only hope this will offer you some cause to consider where your le is going, Judge Savill told him. But Parkinson appeared unconcerned, stretching and yawning loudly as the sentencing hearing drew to a close. How long did I get  How long gets taken off forremand and that  he asked an unseen official in the room at a detention centre where he is being held. Parkinson, of Ashton-under-Lyne, had pleaded guilty to two counts of disqualied driving, two counts of dangerous driving, twice breaching his criminal behaviour order, aggravated vehicle taking, assault causing actual bodily harm and driving without insurance.

title: controlling boyfriend tried keep partner
story: NewsControlling boyfriend tried to keep partner as his virginal sex robot and held her captive for weekChristopher Cooksey called his ex-partners work to say she had been in a car crash, after he had badly beaten herShareCommentsByAdam HaleLiz DayKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsChristopher Cooksey, , flew into a rage after he scrolled through her phone "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA violent thug wanted to keep his partner as his virginal sex robot and held her hostage.Christopher Cooksey ruthlessly beat up his girlfriend and held her captive for a week to hide her injuries.The brute began abusing her after becoming jealous of her previous relationships. A court heard the -year-old started a relationship with Stephanie Watkis, , after meeting her in a gym in September , but weeks later he carried out the first of a string of attacks on her. In one incident in December he found a picture on her phone of a man she had been interested in two years previously. Cooksey, from Pontypool, Gwent, repeatedly punched her while she lay in bed, leaving her with a black eye and a bruised arm before forcing her to drink a bottle of rum. He then kept her as his prisoner for a week to hide her physical injuries and used her phone to tell her employers she would be off work following a car crash.  He also controlled Miss Watkis choice of clothes and make-up, and stole her phone, cutting her off from family and friends after she moved into his flat and rendering her utterly dependent on him. Today, prosecutor Roger Grfiths read a victim impact statement from Miss Watkis, who said she has been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder and depression because of the violent relationship. Miss Watkis said: He always used to say this is not a game and thats what I hear in my nightmares. Hes hugely impacted my social skill and Im now very distrustful of people. Before, I was a bubbly, friendly and welcoming person. I was carefree. This is no longer the case.  Cooksey was found guilty of two counts of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, common assault and  imprisonment following a trial at Newport Crown Court. Harry Baker, defending, told the court at the sentencing hearing that Cooksey had no previous convictions, and both his client and Miss Watkis had admitted it was a bad relationship. Judge Thomas Crowther QC said Cooksey became obsessed with how many other men Miss Watkis had slept with before him. He said: It became very quickly clear that you had a fragile ego, a thin-skinned nature and a vile temper. I have no doubt you wanted Miss Watkis to be your partner, but not as a human, a woman, but rather as a canvas upon which you could project your fantasy image of a woman who had no history, no past, no family, no interest except you.  She didnt match your desire for some blank virginal sex robot. You attacked her, punching her as she lay on the floor curled into a ball, as she put it, like a dog. You isolated her within your home. You made her subject to your dominance.You enforced that by ruthless violence, using your physical power to subjugate her, and by demeaning behaviour. You have caused serious physical and enduring psychological harm. You drove her to the brink of tragedy. Cooksey was given a six-year extended sentence, meaning he will spend four in custody before he is released on licence. He was also given a -year restraining order in relation to Miss Watkis.

title: grieving dad 26 drinks himself
story: NewsGrieving dad, , drinks himself to death after missing rehab place to attend Universal Credit meetingJack Schumanns devastated mum said he was offered a bed at a Drug and Alcohol Inpatient Unit - but instead attended a compulsory meeting about benefitsShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-BillingsSophie Halle-Richards:,  OCT NewsJack suffered with depression after the death of his -month-old daughter in October  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving young dad drank himself to death after missing a rehab place to attend a Universal Credit meeting. Jack Schumann, , suffered with depression ever since the death of his -month-old daughter in October , an inquest heard. The mechanic, from Oldham, Manchester, had been using alcohol as a coping mechanism but quickly developed a dependency, the coroner was told.An inquest into Jacks death heard he would drink up to  cans of cider a day, Manchester Evening News reports.His mother Tracy Schumann believes her son may have been able to tackle the addiction had more services been available to him. She told the coroner Jack had been offered a bed at the Drug and Alcohol Inpatient Unit at Prestwich Hospital in , but she said he missed out after he was forced to attend a meeting about Universal Credit. Have you been affected by Universal Credit  Email webnews@mirror  She added that her son was offered another bed later - which Jack accepted - but claimed he was later told the bed was no longer available. Ms Schumann claimed they never received an explanation and no further attempts were made to offer Jack a bed. Following the inquest, a spokesman for the trust in charge of Prestwich Hospital said they had not had any contact at all with Jack Schumann. The coroner was told by Jacks family he made attempts to beat the addiction by himself, but by May  his health had deteriorated. Jack was found unresponsive by his twin brother on May , this year, and was pronounced dead at the scene by paramedics.  His father, Martin Schumann, told the Heywood hearing on Tuesday: Jack lost his daughter about three years ago and suffered from depression ever since. I think he always blamed himself. He always liked a drink at home, but after her death he would tend to drink a lot. He was drinking about  cans a day. Jack got a job working with me and started to lay off a bit, but in the last  months he started to relapse again. It always got worse around the time of his daughters birthday or anniversary of her death. He adored his daughter and I dont think he ever got over her death. In the last few months he lost a lot of weight - probably about five stone. I last saw him on May  and he didnt look like himself. A postmortem conducted by Dr Abdul Gangrockwala revealed that Jack had died from an alcoholic fatty liver, due to excessive long-term alcohol consumption. He said that although Jacks liver was extensively diseased, the damage was reversible. A toxicology report did not detect any alcohol in Jacks system at the time of his death.  Ms Schumann told the hearing: Jack was offered a meeting at a local rehabilitation centre but it was just horrible. He felt very degraded even though he knew he needed help. We got a call to say that hed been offered a bed at Prestwich but on the same day he was facing eviction from his flat and had to have a meeting about Universal Credit. He was offered another place and he rung to tell me to get everything ready but just after they rang back again and said the bed had gone. We never got any explanation for it. After that there were no other attempts made to offer Jack a bed. In March he was doing really well and trying to cut down on the alcohol but a few weeks before his death his health started to deteriorate. In a statement read to the court, Jacks GP Dr Paul Richbell said the surgery were aware of his alcohol dependency. He said: Jack came to visit me in June  with an alcohol dependency problem and I spoke to him about the alcohol services and he self referred himself for support. He was seen by other doctors at the surgery who offered him advice and put him in touch with the local services.  Assistant Coroner for Manchester North Julie Robertson recorded a conclusion of natural causes. She said: It is clear that Jack used alcohol as a coping strategy. The disease to his liver was extensive and had accumulated over a number of years. I cannot speculate as to whether more available help could have prevented Jacks death. After the hearing Greater Manchester Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust, which runs Prestwich Hospital, said they had not had any contact with Jack Schumann.The Mirror is urging our readers to back our petition to stop the rollout Universal Credit which is plunging families into debt and despair and replace it with a fair system.

story: NewsWhat Meghan and Harry did with all the gts they were given on royal tour - and its sad news for some peopleThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex have received many presents from the public in AustraliaShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video meghan-gets-first-baby-gt-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Harry and Meghan Markle have accepted many lovely gts from the public during their tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have spent a mammoth  days completing  official engagements in the four countries, and have met thousands of people at events and walkabouts. Many have kindly given them presents - including gts such as teddies for their unborn baby, who is due to arrive in spring .Theyve received some odd gts, too. Meghan looked shocked when she was handed a bunch of carrots in Sydney before excitedly telling Harry: Weve got veggies! The carrots were later pictured on the floor with other items given to the couple.  But what exactly happens next  Are they allowed to keep the gts and do they use them  Although each gt-giver would love to think Harry and Meghan will cherish their present forever, they cant possibly use them all. Any present handed to the Duke and Duchess while they are shaking hands at public engagements is classed as an official gt. Every single gt handed to any royal on an official engagement is recorded on a form in order to keep track of them. According to the royal family website, these gts do not become the private property of Meghan and Harry - or any member of royalty who receives them.  The Duke and Duchess presents fall into the official category as they are given by iniduals not personally known to the Member of The Royal Family during walkabouts. If perishable gts with a value of less than pound - like the carrots Meghan was handed in Australia - are not to be personally used by the royalMeghan isnt going to put them into a stew then they may be given to charities or third parties to avoid waste. Third parties include the royals staff, so Meghan could technically pass those carrots on to her royal aides.  Perishable gts with a value over pound which wont be used by the royal recipient should pass to charity. Non-perishable official gts, when not used by the recipient or passed to charity, are stored - and once its in storage, things get a little bit more complicated... These stored gts are reviewed annually by a  of experts from the Royal Household and Royal Collection, who consider each gt in terms of its national, historical, aesthetic or financial value. Then they decide what happens to each gt, which can be:Kept in storage Incorporated into the Royal CollectionLoaned to a reputable and appropriate organisation Donated to a registered charity Destroyedit is not to be retained, loaned or donated to charityGts falling into the first two categories are supposed to be retained for five years. Iniduals and organisations meeting the royal family on official engagements are discouraged from offering extravagant gts. It is not known what the couple will do with all the teddies and baby gts they are being given. They might choose to keep some of them, but as there are so many its likely theyll decide to give some to an appropriate charity so others can benefit from the generosity of their fans.

When they finally arrived at the right hotel at .am, they found most of the rooms were not available, there was nothing to eat or drink, and bedding wasnt ready in some of the rooms that were free. One traveller had an asthma attack climbing the stairs and an ambulance was called.  An angry showdown with a TUI rep occurred the following morning and footage shows the leader of the tourists demanding they are treated like human beings, prompting a massive round of applause. The group had been due to leave Morocco on October  toto Manchester Airport. But serious technical problems with the .pm flight meant they were sent back to Agadir at .am, arriving at .am. But the coach driver dropped the passengers a mile and a half from their emergency hotel accommodation and left before the mistake was realised - taking the seven-year-old boy as well. Passenger Phil Harrison, , from Adlington, Lancashire, recorded the scenes as the tourists tramped through Agadir in a rain storm looking for their accommodation. The clip starts with the sound of thunder and lightning and cuts to Phil saying: “Still walking down the same road. Still not a bleeding rep greeted by anybody. Absolutely disgusting.” The camera then pans around to show tired children dragging suitcases with some mothers carrying their children and a angry tourist shouts while dragging her suitcase: “Women with children. They’re lucky to save this.”  Phil, who emerged as the leader of the group, then goes back to narrating the clip saying “women with children pulling cases. Absolutely disgusting. TUI you are out of order.” The clip then cuts to tourists arriving at the hotel at about .am, tired, soaking and struggling to pull their luggage up the steps. The person filming the clip can be heard panting heavily. The video cuts to the following morning and Phil is filmed addressing a TUI rep, detailing their numerous complaints. To deafening applause and clapping from the dozens of weary travellers, he passionately concludes: From every colour, including race, it doesnt matter, we are all human beings here and we all deserve an explanation! The group finally ed to Manchester at pm on October , a delay admitted by TUI of  hours and  minutes. Zuzana Mestour-Tenkova, , from Manchester, said today: My seven-year old-son was left behind asleep in the coach in that big chaos, due to misunderstanding between me and my husband.  “It was a terrible experience. I still feel sick just thinking about it. We are so disappointed with the way TUI handled this whole situation. Its just disgusting.” Michele Cutts, , from Sheffield, said: “We were traumatised, frantic with worry and let down by TUI. Our families could not get any information on our flight, nothing was announced, it caused unnecessary, in some cases necessary worry on their part. And Esther Mashana said: “I thought it disgusting how we were all denied our basic human rights like water and food. “I remember in the morning I was thirsty. I asked for water at the reception and was told to go to the shops to buy water. “Absolutely appalling. I think its safe to say I wont be using TUI again. Neither will I recommend them to anyone.” A spokeswoman for TUI UK said: “We’re sorry to hear about these customers’ experience. We’ll be looking in to the matter as a priority and will follow up appropriately.”
